The first: from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Hasten to do good deeds before the temptations that are like patches of the dark night. A man will wake up as a believer and go to sleep as a disbeliever, or wake up as a disbeliever and go to sleep as a believer. He will sell his religion for some worldly gain." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The second, from Abu Sarwa'ah - with a kasra and a fatha on the "seen" - Uqbah ibn al-Harith, may Allah be pleased with him, said: I prayed the 'Asr prayer behind the Prophet, peace be upon him, in Medina. He said the tasleem, then stood up quickly and stepped over the necks of the people towards the room of some of his wives. The people were startled by his haste. So he came out to them and saw that they were surprised by his haste. He said: "I remembered something of unrefined gold that I had, and I disliked that it should stay with me. So I ordered it to be distributed." (Narrated by Bukhari). In another narration by Bukhari: "I had left unrefined gold from charity in the house, and I disliked that it should remain with me overnight." (Al-tibr: pieces of gold or silver). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Third: From Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: A man said to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) on the day of Uhud: "What if I am killed, where will I be?" He said: "In Paradise." So he threw the dates that were in his hand, then he fought until he was killed. Agreed upon. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated Abu Huraira: A man came to the Prophet and said, "O Messenger of Allah, which charity brings the greatest reward?" He said, "That you give charity when you are healthy and miserly, fearing poverty and hoping for wealth. And do not delay it until when your soul reaches your throat, you say, 'This is for so-and-so, and this is for so-and-so,' and it has already become for so-and-so." It is agreed upon. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The fifth: Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) took a sword on the day of Uhud and said: "Who will take this from me?" They extended their hands, each one of them saying: "I, I." He said: "And who will take it with its right?" The people hesitated. Abu Dujanah (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "I will take it with its right." So he took it and struck the heads of the polytheists with it. (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Sixth: From Al-Zubayr bin Adi, he said: We came to Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, and complained to him about what we were facing from Al-Hajjaj. He said: "Be patient, for no time will come except that the one after it will be worse than it until you meet your Lord." I heard this from your Prophet, peace be upon him. (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Seventh: From Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Race to do good deeds before seven things. Do you wait for anything but poverty that makes you forget, or wealth that makes you transgress, or sickness that spoils your health, or old age that makes you feeble, or death that suddenly takes you, or the Dajjal – for the Dajjal is an evil absent one to be expected, or the Hour; and the Hour is more bitter and more grievous!" (Tirmidhi) and he said: It is a hasan hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Eighth: It is narrated on his authority that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said on the day of Khaybar: "I will give this banner to a man who loves Allah and His Messenger, and Allah will grant victory through his hands." 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I never desired leadership except on that day, and I vied for it hoping I would be called for it. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, called 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, and gave him the banner, saying: 'Go forth and do not turn back until Allah grants you victory.'" 'Ali proceeded for a while, then stopped and did not turn back, and he cried out: "O Messenger of Allah, on what basis shall I fight the people?" He said: "Fight them until they testify that there is no god but Allah, and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. When they do that, they will have protected from you their blood and their wealth, except by its right, and their reckoning is with Allah." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The first: From Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah the Almighty said: Whoever shows enmity to a saint of Mine, I have declared war on him. And My servant draws not near to Me with anything more beloved to Me than what I have ordained upon him. My servant continues to draw near to Me with voluntary acts of worship until I love him. And when I love him, I become his hearing with which he hears, his sight with which he sees, his hand with which he strikes, and his leg with which he walks. If he asks Me, I will surely grant him. If he seeks refuge in Me, I will surely grant him refuge." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The second: On the authority of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in what he narrates from his Lord, the Mighty and Majestic, he said: "If My servant draws near to Me by a span, I draw near to him by a cubit. If My servant draws near to Me by a cubit, I draw near to him by a fathom. If he comes to Me walking, I come to him running." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Third: It was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Two blessings which many people lose are health and free time." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fourth: From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) used to stand in prayer at night until his feet became swollen. I said to him: "Why do you do this, O Messenger of Allah, when Allah has forgiven your past and future sins?" He said: "Should I not be a grateful servant?" (Agreed upon. This is the wording of Al-Bukhari, and similarly in the two Sahihs from the narration of Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fifth: Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would, when the last ten days of Ramadan began, stay up at night in prayer, wake his family, and gird his loins. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The sixth: From Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) said: "The strong believer is better and more beloved to Allah than the weak believer, and there is good in everyone. Be keen for that which benefits you, and seek help from Allah and do not become helpless. And if anything befalls you, do not say: 'If I had done such and such, it would have been so and so.' Rather, say: 'It is the decree of Allah, and what He has willed He has done,' for 'if' opens the door for the devil." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Seventh: It is narrated from him that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Hell is veiled by desires, and Paradise is veiled by adversities." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The Eighth: It is narrated from Abu Abdullah Hudhaifah bin Al-Yaman, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: "I prayed with the Prophet, peace be upon him, one night. He began to recite Surah Al-Baqarah. I thought, 'He will perform Ruku' at the hundredth verse.' But he continued. I thought, 'He will finish it in one Rak'ah.' But he continued. I thought, 'He will perform Ruku' with it.' Then he began to recite Surah An-Nisa', and he recited it. Then he began to recite Surah Al-Imran, and he recited it. He recited slowly, and when he came to a verse containing glorification, he would glorify [Allah]. When he came to a verse asking a question, he would ask. When he came to a verse of seeking refuge, he would seek refuge. Then he performed Ruku' and began to say: 'Subhana Rabbiyal-Adheem' (Glory be to my Lord, the Most Great). His Ruku' was nearly as long as his standing. Then he said: 'Sami'Allahu liman hamidah, Rabbana walakal-hamd' (Allah hears those who praise Him, our Lord, to You is all praise). Then he stood for a long time, nearly as long as he had been in Ruku'. Then he prostrated and said: 'Subhana Rabbiyal-A'la' (Glory be to my Lord, the Most High). His prostration was nearly as long as his standing." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Ninth: From Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I prayed with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, one night, and he stood for so long that I was about to do something bad! It was asked: What was it that you were about to do? He said: I was about to sit down and leave him. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Tenth, from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Three things follow the deceased: his family, his wealth, and his deeds. Two return and one remains: his family and his wealth return, and his deeds remain." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The eleventh: It was narrated from Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Paradise is closer to one of you than his sandal strap, and Hellfire is like that." (Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Twelfth: From Abu Firas Rabīʿah ibn Kaʿb al-Aslamī, the servant of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and from the People of the Suffah (may Allah be pleased with him), he said: "I used to spend the night with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and I would bring him his ablution water and his needs. He said: 'Ask me.' I said: 'I ask you for your company in Paradise.' He said: 'Or something else?' I said: 'It is that.' He said: 'Then help me against yourself by prostrating a lot.'" (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Thirteenth: From Abu Abdullah – and he was also called Abu Abd al-Rahman – Thawban, the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace), said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) say: "You should prostrate a lot, for you will not prostrate to Allah a prostration but that Allah will raise you a degree by it and forgive a sin for you by it." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The Fourteenth: From Abu Safwan Abdullah bin Busr Al-Aslami, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The best of people is he whose life is long and whose deeds are good." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, who said: It is a Hasan hadith. "Busr": with a damma on the ya and an unpointed sin). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The fifteenth: Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that his uncle Anas bin An-Nadr (may Allah be pleased with him) was absent from the battle of Badr. He said: "O Messenger of Allah, I was absent from the first battle I fought against the polytheists. If Allah witnesses me in a battle against the polytheists, Allah will surely see what I do." When the day of Uhud came, the Muslims suffered a setback. He said: "O Allah, I apologize to You for what these have done - meaning his companions - and I exonerate myself to You from what these have done - meaning the polytheists." Then he advanced, and Sa'd bin Mu'adh met him. He said: "O Sa'd bin Mu'adh, Paradise, by the Lord of the Ka'bah, I find its fragrance from beyond Uhud." Sa'd said: "I was unable to do what he did, O Messenger of Allah!" Anas said: "We found in him eighty-odd wounds from a sword, or a spear thrust, or an arrow shot, and we found him killed and mutilated by the polytheists, so no one recognized him except his sister by his fingertips." Anas said: "We used to see or think that this verse was revealed about him and those like him: 'Among the believers are men who have been true to what they promised Allah.' (Al-Ahzab: 23) to the end of it." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Sixteenth: On the authority of Abu Mas'ud 'Uqbah bin 'Amr Al-Ansari Al-Badri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: When the verse of charity was revealed, we used to carry loads on our backs. Then a man came and gave a lot in charity, and they said: "He is showing off." Then another man came and gave a Sa' (a measure) in charity, and they said: "Allah is indeed self-sufficient and does not need this Sa'!" Then it was revealed: "Those who defame the charitable among the believers and those who do not find except their [ability to give] expenditure..." (At-Tawbah: 79). Agreed upon. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Seventeenth: From Sa'id bin Abd al-Aziz, from Rabi'ah bin Yazid, from Abu Idris al-Khawlani, from Abu Dharr Jundub bin Junadah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, as narrated from Allah, the Blessed and Most High, that He said: "O My servants, I have forbidden injustice upon Myself and made it forbidden among you, so do not wrong one another. O My servants, all of you are astray except those whom I guide, so seek guidance from Me, and I will guide you. O My servants, all of you are hungry except those whom I feed, so seek food from Me, and I will feed you. O My servants, all of you are naked except those whom I clothe, so seek clothing from Me, and I will clothe you. O My servants, you err by night and day, and I forgive all sins, so seek forgiveness from Me, and I will forgive you. O My servants, you will not reach Me to harm Me, nor will you reach Me to benefit Me. O My servants, if your first and last, your humans and jinn, were all to be as pious as the heart of a single man among you, it would not increase My dominion in the least. O My servants, if your first and last, your humans and jinn, were all to be as wicked as the heart of a single man among you, it would not decrease My dominion in the least. O My servants, if your first and last, your humans and jinn, were to stand on a single plain and ask Me, and I gave every person what he asked for, it would not decrease what I have, except as much as a needle decreases the sea when dipped into it. O My servants, it is only your deeds that I count for you, and then I will give them back to you in full. So whoever finds good, let him praise Allah, and whoever finds otherwise, let him blame only himself." Sa'id said: When Abu Idris narrated this hadith, he would kneel on his knees. Narrated by Muslim. (20). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

As for the hadiths, the first is from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "Allah has no excuse to offer a person whose lifespan He has extended until he reaches sixty years of age." (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The second: From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, used to admit me along with the elders of Badr. It was as if some of them felt discontent and said: "Why is he admitted with us when we have sons like him?!" Umar said: "He is of the standing you know!" One day he called me and admitted me with them. I did not think he called me that day except to show them. He said: "What do you say about the saying of Allah the Almighty: 'When the victory of Allah and the conquest come'?" (An-Nasr: 1) Some of them said: "We are commanded to praise Allah and seek His forgiveness when He grants us victory and opens for us." Some of them remained silent and said nothing. Then he said to me: "Do you say the same, O Ibn Abbas?" I said: "No." He said: "What do you say?" I said: "It is the nearing of the end of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, which He informed him of. He said: 'When the victory of Allah and the conquest come,' and that is a sign of your end. 'So glorify the praise of your Lord and seek His forgiveness. Indeed, He was ever Accepting of repentance.'" (Al-Fath: 3) Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I do not know of it except what you say." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The third: It is narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not pray any prayer after the revelation of the verse "When the victory of Allah and the conquest came" except that he would say in it: "Glory be to You, our Lord, and praise be to You, O Allah, forgive me." (Agreed upon). In another narration in the two Sahihs from her: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say frequently in his bowing and prostration: "Glory be to You, O Allah, our Lord, and praise be to You, O Allah, forgive me," interpreting the Quran. In a narration by Muslim: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say frequently before his death: "Glory be to You, O Allah, and praise be to You, I seek Your forgiveness and turn to You in repentance." Aisha said: I said: "O Messenger of Allah, what are these words that I see you have newly started saying?" He said: "A sign has been made for me in my Ummah, and when I see it, I say them: 'When the victory of Allah and the conquest came' to the end of the Surah." In another narration by him: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say frequently: "Glory be to Allah and praise be to Him, I seek Allah's forgiveness and turn to Him in repentance." She said: I said: "O Messenger of Allah! I see you frequently saying: Glory be to Allah and praise be to Him, I seek Allah's forgiveness and turn to Him in repentance?" He replied: "My Lord informed me that I will see a sign in my Ummah, and when I see it, I will frequently say: 'Glory be to Allah and praise be to Him, I seek Allah's forgiveness and turn to Him in repentance.' I have seen it: 'When the victory of Allah and the conquest came' – the conquest of Mecca – 'and you see mankind entering the religion of Allah in crowds, then glorify the praise of your Lord and seek His forgiveness. Indeed, He is ever Accepting of repentance.'" [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The fourth: From Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "Allah Almighty followed up the revelation to the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) before his death, until his death, the revelation was most frequent." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fifth: Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Every servant will be resurrected in the state in which he died." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

First: On the authority of Abu Dharr, Jundub ibn Junadah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I asked, "O Messenger of Allah, which deeds are most excellent?" He replied, "Faith in Allah and striving in His cause." I asked, "Which slaves are most excellent to free?" He replied, "The most valuable to their people and the most expensive." I asked, "What if I cannot do that?" He replied, "Lend a hand to a craftsman or make for a clumsy person." I asked, "O Messenger of Allah, what do you think if I am incapable of some deeds?" He replied, "Refrain from harming people, for that is a charity you give to yourself." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Second: From Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Charity is required for every joint of yours each morning. Every glorification of Allah is charity, every praise of Allah is charity, every declaration that there is no god but Allah is charity, every declaration that Allah is the greatest is charity, enjoining good is charity, and forbidding evil is charity, and two Rak'ahs which one prays during Duha are sufficient for all of that." (Narrated by Muslim) As-Salama: with the pronunciation of the sin with dammah and the lam with sukūn and the mim with fatha: means a joint. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The third narrated from him, he said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "The good and bad deeds of my Ummah were presented to me, and I found among the good deeds the removal of harm from the road, and I found among the bad deeds the phlegm in the mosque that is not buried." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The fourth from him: Some people said: O Messenger of Allah, the wealthy have taken the reward. They pray as we pray, and they fast as we fast, and they give charity from the surplus of their wealth. He said: "Has not Allah made for you something to give in charity? Indeed, every Tasbeeh (glorification of Allah) is a charity, every Takbeer (exaltation of Allah) is a charity, every Tahmeed (praise of Allah) is a charity, every Tahleel (declaration of Allah's oneness) is a charity, enjoining good is a charity, forbidding evil is a charity, and having sexual intercourse with your wife is a charity." They said: O Messenger of Allah, if one of us fulfills his desire, will he have a reward for it? He said: "What do you think if he put it in a forbidden way, would he bear a sin? Likewise, if he puts it in a lawful way, he will have a reward." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The fifth: It was narrated from him that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to me: "Do not belittle any act of kindness, even if it is just meeting your brother with a cheerful face." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Sixth: Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Every joint of the people has a charity every day on which the sun rises: To act justly between two is a charity, to help a man with his mount, carrying him on it, or raising his luggage onto it is a charity, and a good word is a charity, and every step you take towards prayer is a charity, and removing harm from the road is a charity." (Agreed upon). Muslim also narrated it from the narration of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed, every human being of the Children of Adam was created with three hundred and sixty joints. So, whoever glorifies Allah, and praises Allah, and says 'La ilaha illallah' (There is no god but Allah), and glorifies Allah, and seeks forgiveness from Allah, and removes a stone from the path of the people, or a thorn, or a bone from the path of the people, or enjoins good, or forbids evil, for each of these three hundred and sixty, he will be as if he has moved himself away from the Fire that day." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Sixteenth: From Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever prays the two cool prayers will enter Paradise." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
Eighth: From him, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "O Muslim women, let no one of you look down upon the gift of her neighbor, even if it be a hoof of a sheep." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Ninth: He narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he said: "Faith has seventy-odd or sixty-odd branches. The most excellent of them is the saying: 'There is no god but Allah,' and the lowest of them is removing harm from the road. And modesty is a branch of faith." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Tenth: It is narrated from him that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "While a man was walking on a road, he was overcome by thirst. He found a well and descended into it and drank. Then he came out and saw a dog panting, eating the wet earth due to thirst. The man said: 'This dog is suffering from thirst as I was.' So he descended into the well, filled his leather water-skin with water, and held it in his mouth until he climbed out. Then he gave the dog a drink. Allah thanked him for that and forgave him." They said: "O Messenger of Allah, do we get a reward for [treating] animals?" He said: "There is a reward for every wet liver." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The eleventh: From him, from the Prophet, may God bless him and grant him peace, he said: "I saw a man turning in Paradise because of a tree he had cut down from the middle of the road that used to harm Muslims." (Narrated by Muslim). And in one narration: A man passed by a branch of a tree on the road, and said: "By God, I will remove this from the Muslims so that it does not harm them, so he entered Paradise." And in a narration by them both: While a man was walking on a road, he found a branch of thorns on the road, and he moved it, so God thanked him for it and forgave him. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The twelfth: He said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever performs ablution and does it well, then attends Friday prayer, and listens and keeps silent, his sins between that and the previous Friday and three more days will be forgiven. And whoever touches pebbles has engaged in idle talk." (Reported by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Thirteenth: It is narrated from him that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "When a Muslim servant, or a believer, performs ablution and washes his face, every sin which his eyes looked at comes out from his face with the water, or with the last drop of water. And when he washes his feet, every sin which his feet walked to comes out with the water or with the last drop of water, until he comes out pure from sins." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fourteenth: From him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, who said: "The five daily prayers, and from one Friday to the next, and from one Ramadan to the next are expiations for what has occurred between them, provided that the major sins are avoided." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fifteenth: From him, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Shall I not guide you to that by which Allah erases sins and raises ranks?" They said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Performing ablution perfectly despite its being disliked, walking a lot to the mosques, and waiting for prayer after prayer; that is ribat." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Seventh: On his authority, from the Prophet, may God's prayers and peace be upon him, he said: "Whoever goes to the mosque in the morning or in the evening, God prepares for him in Paradise a lodging every time he goes in the morning or in the evening." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Seventeenth: He narrated from him that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When a servant becomes ill or travels, he will have recorded for him the same deeds he used to do when he was resident and healthy." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The eighteenth: From Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Every act of kindness is charity." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari and by Muslim from the narration of Hudhaifah, may Allah be pleased with him). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Nineteenth: From him, it is reported that the Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) said: "There is no Muslim who plants a plant, but whatever is eaten from it is charity for him, and whatever is stolen from it is charity for him, and no one harms it but it is charity for him." (Narrated by Muslim). In another narration by him: "No Muslim plants a plant, and a human, or a beast, or a bird eats from it, but it is charity for him until the Day of Resurrection." And in another narration by him: "No Muslim plants a plant, nor cultivates a crop, and a human, or a beast, or anything eats from it, but it is charity for him." Both of them narrated it from the narration of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The Twentieth: From him, he said: The Banu Salamah wanted to move closer to the mosque, and this reached the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. So he said to them: "It has reached me that you intend to move closer to the mosque?" They said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah, we have intended that." He said: "O Banu Salamah, stay in your homes, your footsteps will be written. Stay in your homes, your footsteps will be written." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Twenty-first: From Abul Mundhir, Ubayy ibn Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: There was a man, I don't know of any man further from the mosque than him, and he never missed prayer. It was said to him, or I said to him: "Why don't you buy a donkey to ride in the darkness and the scorching heat?" He said: "It would not please me that my home was next to the mosque. I want my walking to the mosque and my return when I return to my family to be recorded." Then Allah's Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah has gathered all of that for you." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The twenty-second: narrated on the authority of Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-'As (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Forty good deeds, the highest of them is giving a goat to be milked. Whoever does one of these deeds hoping for its reward and believing in its promise, Allah will admit him to Paradise by it." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The twenty-third: From Adi bin Hatim (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Guard yourselves against the Fire, even if it be with half a date." (Agreed upon). And in a narration for both of them from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There is no one among you but that his Lord will speak to him, with no interpreter between them. He will look to his right and see nothing but what he has sent forward. He will look to his left and see nothing but what he has sent forward. He will look in front of him and see nothing but the Fire facing him. So guard yourselves against the Fire, even if it be with half a date; and if one cannot find that, then with a good word." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The twenty-fourth: Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "Allah is pleased with His servant who eats a meal and praises Him for it, or drinks a drink and praises Him for it." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Twenty-fifth: Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Charity is incumbent upon every Muslim." He was asked: "What if he does not find anything [to give]?" He replied: "Let him help the one who is in need and is distressed." He was asked: "What if he cannot do that?" He said: "Let him command good deeds or good." He was asked: "What if he does not do that?" He said: "Let him refrain from evil, for that is charity." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, entered upon her and there was a woman with her. He said, "Who is this?" She said, "This is so-and-so, who is remembered for her prayer." He said, "Stop! You should do what you can bear. By Allah, Allah does not become weary until you become weary." And the most beloved deed to Allah was that its doer persevered in it. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported: Three men came to the houses of the Prophet's wives and asked about the Prophet's worship. When they were told, they considered their own worship as insignificant and said: "Where are we in comparison to the Prophet (peace be upon him)? Allah has forgiven his past and future sins." One of them said: "As for me, I will pray all night." The other said: "As for me, I will fast all day and never break my fast." The other said: "As for me, I will avoid women and never marry." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) came to them and said: "Are you the ones who said such and such? By Allah, I am the most fearful of Allah and the most pious among you, but I fast and break my fast, I pray and I sleep, and I marry women. Whoever turns away from my Sunnah is not of me." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Destroyed are the extremists." He said this three times. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Religion is easy, and no one outdoes another in it except that he will be overcome. So be steadfast and moderate, and give glad tidings, and seek help by going in the morning, evening, and some of the latter part of the night." (Bukhari) And in a narration by him: "Be steadfast and moderate, go in the morning and evening, and some of the latter part of the night; aim for the middle path, aim for the middle path, and you will reach your goal." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported: The Prophet (peace be upon him) entered the mosque and saw a rope stretched between two pillars. He asked, "What is this rope?" They said, "It is for Zaynab; when she gets tired, she hangs on to it." The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "Untie it. Let each of you pray when he is active, and when he gets tired, he should rest." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may God be pleased with her, that the Messenger of God, may God's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If any one of you dozes off while praying, let him sleep until the sleep leaves him, for if any one of you prays while dozing, he does not know, perhaps he will go and ask for forgiveness and curse himself." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Abdullah, Jabir bin Samurah, may Allah be pleased with them, he said: "I used to pray the prayers with the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his prayer was moderate, and his sermon was moderate." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Juhaifah, Wahb bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him), that the Prophet (peace be upon him) established brotherhood between Salman and Abu Ad-Darda'. Salman visited Abu Ad-Darda' and saw Umm Ad-Darda' in a disheveled state. He asked her, "What is wrong?" She said, "Your brother, Abu Ad-Darda', has no need for worldly things." Abu Ad-Darda' came and prepared food for him. He said to him, "Eat, for I am fasting." Salman replied, "I will not eat until you eat." So Abu Ad-Darda' ate. When it was night, Abu Ad-Darda' got up to pray, but Salman said to him, "Sleep." So he slept. Then Abu Ad-Darda' got up again, and Salman said to him, "Sleep." When it was the last part of the night, Salman said, "Now, get up," and they both prayed. Salman said to him, "Indeed, your Lord has a right over you, and your self has a right over you, and your family has a right over you. So give everyone who has a right their due." Abu Ad-Darda' went to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and mentioned this to him. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "Salman has spoken the truth." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-As, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, was informed that I say: "By Allah, I will fast all day and pray all night as long as I live." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Is it you who says this?" I said to him: "My father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah, I did say it." He said: "You cannot do that. So, fast and break your fast, sleep and pray, and fast three days a month, for a good deed is ten times its like, and that is like fasting the whole year." I said: "I am capable of more than that." He said: "Fast one day and break your fast for two days." I said: "I am capable of more than that." He said: "Fast one day and break your fast for one day. That is the fasting of Prophet David, peace be upon him, and it is the most just fasting." In another narration: "It is the best fasting." I said: "I am capable of more than that." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "There is no better than that." And it is more beloved to me to accept the three days that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said than my family and my wealth. In another narration: "Was I not informed that you fast during the day and pray at night?" I said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Then do not do so. Fast and break your fast, sleep and pray, for your body has a right over you, and your eyes have a right over you, and your wife has a right over you, and your visitor has a right over you. It is sufficient for you to fast three days each month, for you will have ten times the reward for each good deed, and that is like fasting the whole year." So, I strove, and he imposed stricter conditions on me. I said: "O Messenger of Allah, I feel strong." He said: "Fast the fasting of the Prophet of Allah, David, and do not exceed it." I said: "What was the fasting of David?" He said: "Half of the year." Abdullah used to say after he became old: "I wish I had accepted the permission of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him." In another narration: "Was I not informed that you fast all year and recite the entire Quran every night?" I said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah, and I intended nothing but good by that." He said: "Then fast the fasting of the Prophet of Allah, David, for he was the most devout of people, and recite the Quran every month." I said: "O Prophet of Allah, I am capable of more than that?" He said: "Then recite it every twenty days." I said: "O Prophet of Allah, I am capable of more than that?" He said: "Then recite it every ten days." I said: "O Prophet of Allah, I am capable of more than that?" He said: "Then recite it every seven days and do not exceed that." So, I strove, and he imposed stricter conditions on me. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to me: "You do not know, perhaps your life will be prolonged." He said: "So, I followed what the Prophet, peace be upon him, told me. When I became old, I wished that I had accepted the permission of the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him." In another narration: "And your child has a right over you." In another narration: "He who fasts eternally has not fasted," he said it three times. In another narration: "The most beloved fasting to Allah Almighty is the fasting of David, and the most beloved prayer to Allah Almighty is the prayer of David. He used to sleep half the night, pray for a third of it, and sleep for a sixth. He used to fast one day and break his fast for one day, and he would not flee when he encountered the enemy." In another narration, he said: "My father married me to a woman of noble lineage, and he used to visit his daughter-in-law and ask her about her husband. She would say to him: 'He is a good man; he has not shared our bed nor entered our private quarters since we were brought together.' When this continued for a long time, he mentioned it to the Prophet, peace be upon him." He said: "Meet me." So, I met him afterward, and he said: "How do you fast?" I said: "Every day." He said: "And how do you complete the Quran?" I said: "Every night." And he mentioned something similar to what was mentioned before. He used to recite the seven chapters to some of his family, presenting them during the day to make it easier for him at night. And when he wanted to gain strength, he would break his fast for some days and count and fast the like of them, disliking to abandon anything he had parted with from the Prophet, peace be upon him. All these narrations are authentic, most of them are in the two Sahihs and a few of them are in one of them. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Rubai'i, Hanzalah bin Ar-Rabi' al-Asadi, the scribe, one of the scribes of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), he said: Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) met me and said: "How are you, O Hanzalah?" I said: "Hanzalah has become a hypocrite." I said: "Hanzalah has become a hypocrite." (He said: "Glory be to Allah! What are you saying?") I said: "We are with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and he reminds us of Paradise and Hell as if we see them with our own eyes. When we leave the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), we engage with wives, children, and worldly affairs, and we forget much." Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "By Allah, we experience the same thing." So, Abu Bakr and I went until we entered upon the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). I said: "Hanzalah has become a hypocrite, O Messenger of Allah!" The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "And what is that?" I said: "O Messenger of Allah, when we are with you, you remind us of Hell and Paradise as if we see them with our own eyes. When we leave you, we engage with wives, children, and worldly affairs, and we forget much." The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "By Him in whose hand is my soul, if you were to remain in the state you are when you are with me and in remembrance, the angels would shake hands with you on your beds and in your paths. But, O Hanzalah, it is an hour for this and an hour for that," three times. (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, he said: While the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was delivering a sermon, he saw a man standing. He asked about him, and they said: Abu Israel vowed to stand in the sun and not sit, and not seek shade and not speak, and to fast. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Tell him to speak, seek shade, sit, and complete his fast." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Umar ibn Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever sleeps through his portion of the night, or part of it, and then reads it between the Fajr prayer and the Dhuhr prayer, it will be recorded for him as if he read it during the night." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-`Aas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to me: "O Abdullah, do not be like so-and-so; he used to pray at night, but he abandoned praying at night." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: If the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, missed the night prayer due to illness or other reasons, he would pray twelve rak'ahs during the day. (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The first: From Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Leave me as I have left you. Verily, those who were before you were destroyed because of their excessive questioning and their disputes with their prophets. So, when I forbid you anything, abstain from it. And when I command you to do something, do as much of it as you can." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The Second: From Abu Najih Al-Irbad bin Sariyah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) admonished us with a powerful admonition that made our hearts tremble and our eyes shed tears. We said: 'O Messenger of Allah, it is as if it is an admonition of one bidding farewell, so advise us.' He said: 'I advise you to fear Allah, and to listen and obey, even if an Abyssinian slave is appointed over you. And indeed, whoever lives among you will see much disagreement. So you must adhere to my Sunnah and the Sunnah of the rightly guided caliphs. Cling to it with your molars. And beware of newly invented matters, for every innovation is misguidance.'" (Narrated by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Sahih Hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Third: From Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "All of my Ummah will enter Paradise except for those who refuse." It was asked: "And who is it that refuses, O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "Whoever obeys me will enter Paradise, and whoever disobeys me has refused." (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fourth: From Abu Muslim, and it was said: Abu Iyas Salama bin Amr bin Al-Akwa', may Allah be pleased with him, that a man ate with his left hand in front of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He said: "Eat with your right hand." He said: "I cannot." He said: "May you not be able to." Nothing prevented him except arrogance, and he never raised it to his mouth. (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fifth: From Abu Abdullah Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: "Straighten your rows, or Allah will make your faces differ." (Agreed upon). And in a narration of Muslim: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to straighten our rows as if he were straightening an arrow, until when he saw that we had understood him, one day he went out and stood until he was about to say the Takbir, and he saw a man whose chest was protruding. He said: "O servants of Allah, straighten your rows, or Allah will make your faces differ." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The sixth: On the authority of Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: A house in Medina burned down with its people in it during the night. When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was told about them, he said: "This fire is an enemy to you, so when you go to sleep, extinguish it." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Seventh: It is narrated from him, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The example of what Allah has sent me with of guidance and knowledge is like rain that fell upon a land. Part of it was good, it absorbed the water and produced abundant grass and vegetation. Another part of it held the water, and Allah benefited people with it, so they drank from it, watered (their animals), and cultivated. And another part of it was barren land that neither held water nor produced vegetation. This is an example of a person who understands the religion of Allah and benefits from what Allah has sent me with, so he learns and teaches. And it is an example of a person who pays no attention to it and does not accept the guidance of Allah with which I have been sent." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Eighth: From Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) said: "My parable and your parable is like a man who kindled a fire, and the moths and the insects fell into it. He pushed them away, but they rushed into it. So I am holding you back from the fire, but you are breaking away from my hands." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Ninth: It is narrated from him that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) ordered licking the fingers and the dish, saying: "You do not know in which of it is the blessing." (Narrated by Muslim). And in another narration from him: "If a morsel falls from any of you, let him pick it up and remove any dirt from it, and eat it, and not leave it for Satan, and not wipe his hand with a handkerchief until he licks his fingers, for he does not know in which of his food is the blessing." And in another narration from him: "Satan attends any of you in all his affairs until he attends him at his food. So if a morsel falls from any of you, let him remove any dirt from it and eat it, and not leave it for Satan." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Tenth: From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood before us and gave a sermon, saying: "O people, you will be gathered to Allah, the Almighty, barefoot, naked, and uncircumcised. {As We initiated the first creation, We shall reproduce it; a promise binding upon Us. Indeed, We shall fulfill it.} (Al-Anbiya: 103) Know that the first of creation to be clothed on the Day of Resurrection will be Ibrahim, peace be upon him. Know that men from my Ummah will be brought, and they will be taken to the left. I will say: 'O Lord, my companions!' It will be said: 'You do not know what they innovated after you.' I will say as the righteous servant said: {And I was a witness over them as long as I was among them} until the end of the verse: {The Almighty, the Wise.} (Al-Ma'idah: 117, 118) Then it will be said to me: 'They have been continuously turning back on their heels since you left them.'" (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The eleventh: It is narrated from Abu Sa'id Abdullah bin Mughaffal, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade throwing pebbles with the thumb and forefinger, and said: "It does not hunt prey, nor does it wound an enemy, but it does blind the eye and break the tooth." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from 'Abis bin Rabiah, he said: I saw 'Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) kissing the Stone, meaning the Black Stone, and saying: "I know that you are a stone, you neither harm nor benefit, and were it not for the fact that I saw the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) kissing you, I would not have kissed you." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: When the following verse was revealed to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "To Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. Whether you show what is within yourselves or conceal it, Allah will bring you to account for it." (Al-Baqarah: 283) This was very hard on the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. So they came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, then they knelt on their knees and said: O Messenger of Allah, we have been burdened with deeds that we can bear: prayer, jihad, fasting, and charity, and this verse has been revealed to you, and we cannot bear it. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do you want to say, as the People of the Two Books before you said: 'We hear and we disobey'? Rather, say: 'We hear and we obey; [we seek] Your forgiveness, our Lord, and to You is the [final] destination.'" When the people recited it, and their tongues became accustomed to it, Allah Almighty revealed thereafter: "The Messenger has believed in what was revealed to him from his Lord, and [so have] the believers. All of them have believed in Allah, His angels, His books, and His messengers. [They say], 'We make no distinction between any of His messengers.' And they say, 'We hear and we obey. [We seek] Your forgiveness, our Lord, and to You is the [final] destination.'" When they did that, Allah Almighty abrogated it, and Allah the Almighty revealed: "Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity. It will have [the burden of] what [good] it has gained, and it will bear [the burden of] what [evil] it has earned. Our Lord, do not impose blame upon us if we have forgotten or erred." He said: Yes. "Our Lord, and burden us not with an individual [burden] as You burdened those before us." He said: Yes. "Our Lord, and do not burden us with that which we have no strength to bear." He said: Yes. "And pardon us; and forgive us; and have mercy upon us. You are our protector, so give us victory over the disbelieving people." He said: Yes." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever introduces into our affair something that is not part of it, it is rejected." (Agreed upon). And in a narration of Muslim: "Whoever performs an act that is not in accordance with our affair, it is rejected." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when he delivered a sermon, his eyes would redden, his voice would rise, and his anger would intensify, as if he were warning an army, saying: "Morning and evening." And he would say: "I have been sent and the Hour are like these two," and he would join his fingers, the index finger and the middle finger, and say: "Now then, the best of speech is the Book of Allah, and the best of guidance is the guidance of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and the worst of matters are their innovations, and every innovation is a deviation." Then he would say: "I am closer to every believer than himself. Whoever leaves wealth, it is for his family, and whoever leaves debt or dependents, it is for me to bear." (Narrated by Muslim). And from Al-Irbad ibn Sariyah, may Allah be pleased with him, his previous hadith in the chapter on adhering to the Sunnah. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Abu Amr Jarir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that we were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in the early part of the day. Some people came to him, naked, wearing only cloaks or cloaks, with swords hanging from their necks, most of them from the tribe of Mudar, or rather all of them from Mudar. The face of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, changed when he saw their destitution. He went in and then came out and ordered Bilal to call the Adhan and Iqama. He prayed and then delivered a sermon. He said: "O mankind, fear your Lord who created you from a single soul..." to the end of the verse: "Indeed, Allah has been an Observer over you." And the other verse at the end of Al-Hashr: "O you who have believed, fear Allah, and let every soul look to what it has put forth for the morrow. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is acquainted with what you do." A man gave from his dinar, from his dirham, from his garment, from his sa' of barley, from his sa' of dates, until he said: "Even if it be half a date." Then an Ansari man came with a bundle of goods that his hand could scarcely carry, nay, it could not carry it. Then people followed suit until I saw two heaps of food and clothes. I even saw the face of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, shining as if it were gold. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever initiates a good practice in Islam will have the reward of it and the reward of all those who follow him after him, without diminishing their rewards in any way. And whoever initiates a bad practice in Islam will have the burden of it and the burden of all those who follow him after him, without diminishing their burdens in any way." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "No soul is unjustly killed except that the first son of Adam bears a share of its blood, because he was the first to establish killing." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Mas'ud 'Uqbah bin 'Amr Al-Ansari Al-Badri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever guides to good has the like of the reward of the one who does it." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever calls to guidance, he shall have a reward like the rewards of those who follow him, without their rewards being diminished in any way. And whoever calls to misguidance, he shall bear the sin like the sins of those who follow him, without their sins being diminished in any way." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Al-Abbas, Sahl bin Sa'd Al-Sa'idi (may Allah be pleased with him), that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said on the day of Khaybar: "I will give the banner tomorrow to a man through whom Allah will grant victory, who loves Allah and His Messenger, and Allah and His Messenger love him." The people spent their night discussing who would be given it. When morning came, the people went to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), each hoping to be given it. He said: "Where is Ali bin Abi Talib?" It was said: "O Messenger of Allah, he is suffering from his eyes." He said: "Send for him." He was brought, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) spat in his eyes and prayed for him, and he recovered as if he had never had any pain. He was given the banner. Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "O Messenger of Allah, should I fight them until they become like us?" He said: "Proceed gently until you descend into their courtyard, then invite them to Islam, and inform them of the rights of Allah Almighty over them. For by Allah, if Allah guides one man through you, it is better for you than red camels." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that a young man from Aslam said: "O Messenger of Allah, I wish to go on an expedition, but I have nothing to equip myself with." He said: "Go to so-and-so, for he had prepared himself for an expedition but fell ill." He went to him and said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sends you his greetings and says: 'Give me what you prepared yourself with.'" He said: "O so-and-so, give him what you prepared yourself with, and do not withhold anything from him, for by Allah, if you withhold anything from him, it will not be blessed for you." (Reported by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Abu Abd al-Rahman Zayd ibn Khalid al-Juhani, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever equips a warrior for the sake of Allah has indeed waged war, and whoever looks after a warrior's family in his absence with good has indeed waged war." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent an expedition to Banu Lihyan of Hudhayl and said: "Let one of every two men go forth, and the reward shall be shared between them." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, met a caravan in Ruha', and he said: "Who are you?" They said: "Muslims." They said: "And who are you?" He said: "The Messenger of Allah." Then a woman raised a boy to him and said: "Does he have Hajj?" He said: "Yes, and you have a reward." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated from Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The Muslim treasurer who is trustworthy and carries out what he is commanded to do, giving it fully and completely, willingly, is one of the charitable givers." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The first: From Abu Ruqayyah Tamim bin Aws Ad-Dari (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The religion is sincerity." We said: "To whom?" He said: "To Allah, His Book, His Messenger, the leaders of the Muslims, and their common people." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The second: Narrated by Jarir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: I pledged allegiance to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to establish prayer, give zakat, and offer sincere advice to every Muslim. (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Third: From Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "None of you believes until he loves for his brother what he loves for himself." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The first: From Abu Sa'id al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: "Whoever among you sees something wrong, let him change it with his hand. If he cannot, then with his tongue. If he cannot, then with his heart, and that is the weakest of faith." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Second: From Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There is no prophet whom Allah sent among a nation before me, except that he had among his nation disciples and companions who followed his Sunnah and followed his command. Then after them, successors came who said what they did not do and did what they were not commanded. So whoever strives against them with his hand, he is a believer; whoever strives against them with his heart, he is a believer; and whoever strives against them with his tongue, he is a believer. And there is not beyond that the weight of a mustard seed of faith." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The Third: From Abu al-Walid 'Ubadah ibn al-Samit, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "We pledged allegiance to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to listen and obey in hardship and ease, in eagerness and reluctance, and to give preference to others over ourselves, and not to dispute the matter with its rightful owners, unless we see manifest disbelief, for which we have a clear proof from Allah the Almighty. And to speak the truth wherever we are, not fearing the blame of any blamer in Allah." (Agreed upon) Al-Minsah and al-Makrooh, with the opening of their meem: meaning in ease and hardship. Al-Atharah: is to single out for oneself something that is shared. Its explanation has preceded. Bawahan, with the opening of the baa, followed by waw, then alif, then haa, unpointed: meaning apparent, not admitting of interpretation. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fourth: From An-Nu'man bin Bashir, may Allah be pleased with them, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "The likeness of the one who upholds Allah's limits and the one who transgresses them is like people who drew lots for a ship. Some of them ended up in the upper part and some in the lower part. Those in the lower part, when they wanted to draw water, would pass by those above them, and they said: 'If we were to make a hole in our part of the ship, we would not bother those above us.' If they were to leave them to what they intended, they would all perish. And if they took them by the hands, they would all be saved." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fifth: From the Mother of the Believers, Umm Salamah Hind bint Abi Umayyah Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "There will be rulers over you, whom you will recognize and whom you will reject. Whoever rejects [their deeds] is absolved, and whoever denounces [their deeds] is safe. But whoever accepts and follows [their deeds]..." They said: "O Messenger of Allah, shall we not fight them?" He said: "No, as long as they establish the prayer among you." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Sixth: From the Mother of the Believers, Umm al-Hakam, Zaynab bint Jahsh, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, entered upon her, fearful, saying: "There is no god but Allah. Woe to the Arabs from an evil that has drawn near. Today a gap has opened in the dam of Gog and Magog like this," and he made a circle with his thumb and the finger next to it. I said: "O Messenger of Allah, shall we be destroyed while there are righteous people among us?" He said: "Yes, when wickedness becomes widespread." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Seventh: From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him), from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "Beware of sitting in the roads." They said: "O Messenger of Allah, we have no choice but to sit in them; we talk there!" The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "If you must sit, then give the road its due." They said: "And what is the due of the road, O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "Lowering the gaze, refraining from harm, returning the greeting, enjoining good, and forbidding evil." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Eighth: From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saw a gold ring on a man's hand. He snatched it and threw it away, saying: "Does one of you take a burning coal from hellfire and put it on his hand?!" It was said to the man after the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had left: "Take your ring, benefit from it." He said: "By Allah, I will never take it, for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, has thrown it away." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Ninth: From Abu Sa'id Al-Hasan Al-Basri, that 'A'idh bin 'Amr (may Allah be pleased with him) entered upon 'Ubaidullah bin Ziyad and said: "O son, I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: 'The worst of shepherds are the harsh ones.' So beware of being among them." He replied to him: "Sit down, for you are among the chaff of the companions of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him)." He said: "Were there any chaff among them? The chaff came after them and among others!" (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Tenth: On the authority of Hudhaifah (may Allah be pleased with him), from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "By Him in Whose hand is my soul, you must enjoin good and forbid evil, or Allah will surely send upon you a punishment from Him, then you will call upon Him and He will not answer you." (Narrated by Tirmidhi and he said: A hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The eleventh: It is narrated from Abu Sa'eed Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: "The best of jihad is a word of justice spoken to a tyrannical ruler." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and At-Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

The Twelfth: From Abu Abdullah Tariq bin Shihab Al-Bajali Al-Ahmasi, may Allah be pleased with him, that a man asked the Prophet, peace be upon him, as he was placing his foot in the stirrup: "Which jihad is best?" He said: "A word of truth before a tyrannical ruler." (Narrated by Al-Nasa'i with a sound chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Thirteenth: From Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The first thing that brought deficiency to the Children of Israel was that a man would meet a man and say: 'O you, fear Allah and leave what you are doing, for it is not permissible for you.' Then he would meet him the next day and he was still in the same state, and this did not prevent him from being his companion in eating, drinking, and sitting. When they did that, Allah struck the hearts of some of them with others." Then he said: "{Cursed were those among the Children of Israel who disbelieved through the tongue of David and Jesus the son of Mary. That was because they disobeyed and were accustomed to transgress. They used to not forbid one another from wrongdoing which they committed. How evil was that which they used to do. You see many of them taking as protectors those who disbelieved. How evil is that which their souls have sent forth for them...} [Al-Ma'idah: 78-81] ...until His saying: {...defiantly disobedient.} [Al-Ma'idah: 81] Then he said: "No, by Allah, you must enjoin good and forbid evil, and you must seize the hand of the wrongdoer and compel him to the truth, and restrict him to the truth, or Allah will strike the hearts of some of you with others, and then He will curse you as He cursed them." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan hadith). This is the wording of Abu Dawud, and the wording of Al-Tirmidhi is: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When the Children of Israel fell into sins, their scholars forbade them, but they did not desist. So they sat with them in their gatherings, ate with them, and drank with them. So Allah struck the hearts of some of them with others, and cursed them through the tongue of David and Jesus the son of Mary, because they disobeyed and were accustomed to transgress." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sat down, and he was leaning, and said: "No, by Him in whose hand is my soul, until you compel them to the truth, compelling them." The saying: "compel them" means to turn them. And "restrict him" means to imprison him. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Fourteenth: From Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: O people, you recite this verse: {O you who have believed, upon you is [responsibility for] yourselves. Those who have gone astray will not harm you when you are guided.} (Al-Ma'idah: 105). And I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Indeed, when people see the oppressor and do not take him by the hand (i.e., stop him), it is likely that Allah will encompass them with punishment from Him." (Reported by Abu Dawud, At-Tirmidhi, and An-Nasa'i with authentic chains of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Zayd Usama bin Zayd bin Harithah, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: "A man will be brought on the Day of Resurrection and thrown into the Fire, and his intestines will spill out, and he will go around with them as a donkey goes around a millstone. The people of the Fire will gather around him and say: 'O so-and-so, what is wrong with you? Did you not used to enjoin good and forbid evil?' He will say: 'Yes, I used to enjoin good but not do it, and I used to forbid evil but do it.'" (Agreed upon) His saying: "tindlaqu" is with the unpointed "dāl", and it means "to come out". And "al-aqṭāb" are the intestines, the singular of which is "qutb". [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The signs of a hypocrite are three: when he speaks, he lies; when he makes a promise, he breaks it; and when he is entrusted, he is treacherous." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated on the authority of Hudhayfah ibn al-Yaman (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) told us two Hadith. I have seen one of them, and I am waiting for the other. He told us that trust was sent down into the roots of men's hearts, then the Qur'an was sent down, and they learned from the Qur'an and learned from the Sunnah. Then he told us about the lifting of trust, and said: "A man sleeps, and trust is taken from his heart, and its trace remains like a spot. Then he sleeps again, and trust is taken from his heart, and its trace remains like the mark of a blister, like a coal rolled over your foot, which causes it to swell, and you see it raised, but there is nothing in it." Then he took a pebble and rolled it over his foot. "People will begin to trade with one another, and hardly anyone will fulfill their trust, until it is said: 'In the tribe of so-and-so there is a trustworthy man,' until it is said to a man: 'How strong he is! How witty he is! How intelligent he is!' And there is not in his heart a mustard seed's weight of faith. And a time came upon me when it did not matter to me who I traded with. If he was a Muslim, his religion would bring it back to me. If he was a Christian or a Jew, his tax collector would bring it back to me. But today, I would not trade with any of you except so-and-so and so-and-so." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Hudhaifah and Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with them both, they said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, will gather the people, and the believers will stand until Paradise is brought near to them. They will come to Adam, peace be upon him, and say: 'O our father, ask for the opening of Paradise for us.' He will say: 'Was it not your father's sin that expelled you from Paradise? I am not the one for that. Go to my son Abraham, the friend of Allah.' He said: 'They will come to Abraham, and Abraham will say: I am not the one for that. Go to Moses, to whom Allah spoke directly.' They will come to Moses, and he will say: 'I am not the one for that. Go to Jesus, the Word of Allah and His Spirit.' Jesus will say: 'I am not the one for that.' They will come to Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, and he will stand and be given permission. And the trusts and the wombs will be sent and stand on the sides of the As-Sirat, to the right and to the left. Then the first of you will pass like lightning." I said: "May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, what is like passing like lightning?" He said: "Did you not see how he passes and returns in the blink of an eye? Then like the wind, then like the birds, and the strongest of men will be carried by their deeds, and your Prophet will be standing on the As-Sirat saying: 'O Lord, save, save,' until the deeds of the servants are accounted for, until a man comes who cannot walk except by crawling. And on the sides of the As-Sirat are hanging hooks that are commanded to seize whom they are commanded. So, whoever is scratched is saved, and whoever is thrown in is in the Fire.' And by the One in whose hand is the soul of Abu Hurairah, the bottom of Hell is seventy autumns' journey." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Khubayb - with the letter Khā’ prefixed and pronounced with dammah - Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: When Al-Zubayr stood on the day of the Camel, he called me and I stood next to him. He said: "My son, no one will be killed today except an oppressor or the oppressed. And I do not see myself except that I will be killed today as the oppressed. And one of my greatest concerns is my debt. Do you think our religion will leave anything of our wealth?" Then he said: "My son, sell our property and pay off my debt, and bequeath a third, and a third of that to my sons." He meant the sons of Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr, a third of the third. He said: "If there is anything left of our wealth after paying the debt, then a third of it is for your sons." Hisham said: "And some of Abdullah's children were equivalent to some of Al-Zubayr's children, Khubayb and Abbad, and he had nine sons and nine daughters at that time." Abdullah said: "He kept advising me about his debt and saying: 'My son, if you are unable to do anything about it, then seek help from my Master.'" He said: "By Allah, I did not know what he meant until I said: 'My father, who is your Master?' He said: 'Allah.' He said: 'By Allah, I never encountered any distress regarding his debt except that I said: 'O Master of Al-Zubayr, pay off his debt,' and it was paid off." He said: "Al-Zubayr was killed and left no dinar or dirham except for some lands, including Al-Ghabah and eleven houses in Medina, and two houses in Basra, and a house in Kufa, and a house in Egypt." He said: "And the debt that he owed was because a man used to bring him money and entrust it to him, and Al-Zubayr would say: 'No, but it is a loan, for I fear it will be lost.' And he never held any governorship, nor collected taxes, nor tribute, nor anything except when he was on a raid with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, or with Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman, may Allah be pleased with them." Abdullah said: "I calculated what his debt was and found it to be two million two hundred thousand!" Then Hakim bin Hizam met Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr and said: "Nephew, how much debt does my brother have?" I concealed it from him and said: "One hundred thousand." Hakim said: "By Allah, I do not think your wealth is enough for this!" Abdullah said: "What if it were one million and two hundred thousand?" He said: "I do not think you can afford this. If you are unable to do anything about it, then seek my help." He said: "Al-Zubayr had bought Al-Ghabah for one hundred and seventy thousand, and Abdullah sold it for one million six hundred thousand. Then he stood and said: 'Whoever has a claim against Al-Zubayr, let him meet us at Al-Ghabah.' Abdullah bin Ja'far came to him, and he had four hundred thousand against Al-Zubayr. He said to Abdullah: 'If you wish, I can leave it for you?' Abdullah said: 'No.' He said: 'Then if you wish, you can include it in what you postpone if you postpone.' Abdullah said: 'No.' He said: 'Then allocate a portion for me.' Abdullah said: 'From here to here for you.'" Abdullah sold from it and paid off his debt and compensated him, and four and a half shares remained. He went to Muawiyah, and with him were Amr bin Uthman, Al-Mundhir bin Al-Zubayr, and Ibn Zam'ah. Muawiyah said to him: "How much did you value Al-Ghabah at?" He said: "Each share at one hundred thousand." He said: "How much remains?" He said: "Four and a half shares." Al-Mundhir bin Al-Zubayr said: "I have taken a share from it for one hundred thousand." Amr bin Uthman said: "I have taken a share from it for one hundred thousand." Ibn Zam'ah said: "I have taken a share from it for one hundred thousand." Muawiyah said: "How much remains?" He said: "One and a half shares." He said: "I have taken it for one hundred and fifty thousand." He said: "And Abdullah bin Ja'far sold his share to Muawiyah for six hundred thousand." When Ibn Al-Zubayr finished paying his debt, the sons of Al-Zubayr said: "Divide our inheritance among us." He said: "By Allah, I will not divide it among you until I announce in the pilgrimage for four years: 'Behold, whoever has a debt against Al-Zubayr, let him come to us so we can pay it off.'" He used to announce every year during the pilgrimage, and after four years had passed, he divided it among them and gave the third.
