And Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, used to say: "When you enter upon the evening, do not await the morning, and when you enter upon the morning, do not await the evening. And take from your health for your illness, and from your life for your death." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu al-Abbas Sahl bin Sa'd al-Sa'idi, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: A man came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah, guide me to a deed that if I do it, Allah will love me and people will love me. He said: "Be ascetic in this world, and Allah will love you. Be ascetic in what people possess, and people will love you." (A hasan hadith narrated by Ibn Majah and others with hasan chains of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: 'Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, mentioned what people had attained of worldly things, and said: "I have seen the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, passing the day twisting and turning, not finding a date fit to fill his stomach." (Narrated by Muslim). Ad-Daqla: With the opening of the unpointed Dal and Qaf, it means bad dates. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) died, and there was nothing in my house that a living being could eat except half a measure of barley on a shelf of mine. I ate from it until it lasted a long time for me, and then I ate it until it was all gone. (Agreed upon) "Half a measure of barley" means some barley, as explained by Al-Tirmidhi. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Amr bin Al-Harith, brother of Juwairiyah bint Al-Harith, mother of the believers, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, did not leave at his death a dinar or a dirham, nor a slave, nor a bondwoman, nor anything except his white mule which he used to ride, his weapons, and land which he made sadaqah for the wayfarer." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Khabbab bin Al-Aratt, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: "We migrated with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, seeking the face of Allah Almighty. So our reward fell upon Allah. Some of us died and did not eat anything from their reward, among them was Mus'ab bin Umayr, may Allah be pleased with him. He was killed on the day of Uhud and left behind a nimrah. When we covered his head with it, his feet appeared, and when we covered his feet with it, his head appeared. So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered us to cover his head and place some idhkhir on his feet. And some of us whose fruit had ripened, they would pick it. (Agreed upon). An-nimrah: a colored woolen cloak. And his saying: 'ain'at, meaning: it ripened and matured. And his saying: 'yahdiha' (with fat-ha on the ya and damma on the dal, and kasra on it, two pronunciations); meaning: he picks it and gathers it. And this is a metaphor for what Allah Almighty opened for them of the world and their ability in it." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sahl ibn Sa'd As-Sa'idi, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If the world were worth the wing of a mosquito in the sight of Allah, He would not give a disbeliever a sip of water from it." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, and he said it is a hasan sahih hadith) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Verily, this world is cursed, and cursed is all that is in it, except for the remembrance of Allah the Most High and what follows it, and a scholar and a student." (Tirmidhi narrated it and said: It is a Hasan hadith.) (Tirmidhi narrated it and said: It is a Hasan hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not take on livelihoods so that you may desire the world." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and said: It is a good hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-As, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by us while we were repairing a fence for us. He said: "What is this?" We said: It has become weak, so we are repairing it. He said: "I do not see the matter except that it is more urgent than that." Narrated by Abu Dawud and Tirmidhi with a chain of narration similar to that of Bukhari and Muslim. And Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ka'b bin 'Ayad, may Allah be pleased with him, he said that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Indeed, for every nation there is a trial, and the trial of my nation is wealth." (Reported by At-Tirmidhi and said: A hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Amr, and it is said: Abu Abdullah; and it is said: Abu Layla, Uthman ibn Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "A son of Adam has no right to anything other than these things: a house to live in, a garment to cover his shame, coarse bread, and water." (Narrated by Tirmidhi and said: it is a sahih hadith). (Tirmidhi said: I heard Abu Dawud Sulaiman bin Salim Al-Balkhi say: I heard Al-Nadr bin Shumail say: Al-jalf: bread without any accompaniment. Others said: it is coarse bread. Al-Harawi said: what is meant here is a container for bread; like a sack or a pouch, and Allah knows best). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Al-Shikhair, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: I came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was reciting: "Alhakum al-takathur." He said: "The son of Adam says: My wealth! And what do you have of your wealth, O son of Adam, except what you have eaten and consumed, or what you have worn and made old, or what you have given away in charity and sent forth?" (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Mughaffal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A man said to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "O Messenger of Allah, by Allah, I love you." He said: "Look at what you are saying." He said: "By Allah, I love you," three times. He said: "If you love me, then prepare yourself for poverty as a horse prepares for its saddle, for poverty is swifter to those who love me than a torrent is to its destination." (Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan hadith.)

'Al-Tajaffuf' (تجفاف) is with a kasra on the 'ta' (ت), sukoon on the 'jeem' (ج), and a repeated 'fa' (ف). It is something worn by a horse to protect it from harm, and humans may also wear it. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ka'b bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Two hungry wolves sent among sheep do not cause more ruin to them than a man's greed for wealth and honor does to his religion." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said: It is a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, slept on a mat, and it had left an impression on his side. We said: "O Messenger of Allah, if we had made a bed for you!" He said: "What is the matter with me and this world? I am in this world but like a rider who rested under a tree, then he left it and went away." (Narrated by Tirmidhi and said: It is a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The poor will enter Paradise before the rich by five hundred years." (Narrated by Tirmidhi and he said: This is a sound hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas and Imran bin Husain, may Allah be pleased with them, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "I looked into Paradise and saw that most of its inhabitants were the poor, and I looked into Hellfire and saw that most of its inhabitants were women." (Agreed upon, narrated by Ibn Abbas). (Also narrated by Bukhari from the narration of Imran bin Husain). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Usamah ibn Zayd, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "I stood at the gate of Paradise, and most of those who entered it were the poor. And the wealthy were detained, except for the people of the Fire, they have been ordered to the Fire." (Agreed upon). And (al-Jidd: fortune and wealth. This hadith has previously been explained in the chapter on the virtue of the weak). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "The truest word a poet ever spoke is the word of Labīd: 'Indeed, all things except Allah are in vain.'" (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The family of Muhammad, peace be upon him, did not eat their fill of barley bread for two consecutive days until he passed away. (Agreed upon). In another narration: The family of Muhammad, peace be upon him, did not eat their fill of wheat food for three consecutive nights since they came to Medina until he passed away. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Urwah, from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that she used to say: "By Allah, my nephew, we would see the crescent moon, then the crescent moon: three crescents in two months, and no fire was lit in the houses of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him." I said: "Aunt, what did you live on?" She said: "The two black things: dates and water. Except that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had neighbors from the Ansar, and they had milch camels, and they would send some of their milk to the Messenger of Allah, and he would give it to us to drink." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'id al-Maqburi, from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that he passed by some people who had a roasted sheep in front of them. They invited him to eat, but he refused and said: "Allah's Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him) left this world and had never eaten his fill of barley bread." (Reported by Al-Bukhari). 'Mussalyah' with the opening of the 'Meem' means roasted. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Prophet (peace be upon him) did not eat on a dining table until he died, nor did he eat thin bread until he died. (Reported by Bukhari) In another narration by him: "Nor did he ever see a roasted sheep with his own eyes." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: I saw your Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and he did not find enough of the bad dates to fill his stomach. (Reported by Muslim). (Bad dates: inferior dates). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sahl bin Sa'd (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: "I never saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) seeing *al-naqi'* since Allah sent him until Allah took him back." It was said to him: "Did you have sieves in the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)?" He said: "I never saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) see a sieve since Allah sent him until Allah took him back." It was said to him: "How did you eat barley that was not sifted?" He said: "We used to grind it and blow on it, so whatever flew away flew away, and whatever remained, we would wet it and knead it." (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) went out one day or night, and he met Abu Bakr and Umar (may Allah be pleased with them). He said: "What has brought you out of your houses at this hour?" They said: "Hunger, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "By Him in Whose Hand is my soul, hunger has brought me out, too. Come along." So they got up and went with him.

He went to a man of the Ansar, and he was not in his house. When the woman saw him, she said: "Welcome and greetings." Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) said to her: "Where is so-and-so?" She said: "He has gone to fetch us fresh water."

Then the Ansar came and looked at Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) and his two companions, and said: "Praise be to Allah! No one today is being honored as a guest more than I." He went and brought them a bunch of unripe dates, dates, and fresh dates. He said: "Eat." He took a knife, and Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) said: "Do not slaughter the milk-giving one." He slaughtered (a sheep) for them, and they ate of the sheep and of that bunch of dates, and drank.

When they had eaten their fill and drunk their fill, Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) said to Abu Bakr and Umar (may Allah be pleased with them): "By Him in Whose Hand is my soul, you will be asked about this bliss on the Day of Resurrection. Hunger brought you out of your houses, and you did not return until you had obtained this bliss." (Reported by Muslim).

(Her saying: "to fetch" means to seek fresh, sweet water. And "a bunch of dates" is the cluster of dates. And "a knife" is the knife. And "milk-giving" means giving milk. And the question about the Ansar whom they came to is Abu Al-Haytham bin Al-Tihhan (may Allah be pleased with him), as it is stated in the narration of Al-Tirmidhi and others.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Khalid bin Umar Al-Adawi, he said: Utbah bin Ghazwan, who was the governor of Basra, addressed us. He praised Allah and extolled Him, then he said: "To proceed; indeed, the world has announced its departure and has passed swiftly. Nothing remains of it but a remnant like the leftover water in a vessel that its owner sips. You will be moved from it to an abode of permanence. So move with the best you have at hand. It has been told to us that a stone is cast from the edge of Hell, and it falls for seventy years without reaching its bottom. By Allah, it will be filled... Are you surprised! It has been told to us that the distance between two leaves of the gates of Paradise is a journey of forty years, and a day will come when it will be packed with people. I saw myself as the seventh of seven with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. We had no food but tree leaves until our mouths were sore. I found a cloak and tore it in half between myself and Sa'd bin Malik. I wore half of it as a lower garment, and Sa'd wore the other half. Today, none of us woke up except he was a governor of one of the provinces. I seek refuge in Allah from being great in myself and small before Allah." (Narrated by Muslim). His statement "aadhana" is with a lengthened alif, meaning: announced. And his statement "bisurmin" is with a dhamma on the sad, meaning: its severance and its passing. And his statement "wa wallat hidhaa'" is with an unpointed haa' (ح) followed by a stressed dhal (ذ) and then a lengthened alif, meaning: swiftly. And "as-sababa" is with a dhamma on the unpointed sad (ص), meaning: a little remainder. And his statement "yatasaabahaa" is with a shadda on the baa' (ب) before the haa' (ه), meaning: gathers it. And "al-kadhith" means: abundant and full. And his statement "qarihat" is with a fatha on the qaaf (ق) and a kasra on the raa' (ر), meaning: it developed sores. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Musa al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, brought out for us a thick cloak and a loincloth, and said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, died in these. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "I was the first of the Arabs to shoot an arrow in the cause of Allah, and we used to campaign with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and our food was nothing but the leaves of the *halbah* and the *samr*. So much so that one of us would digest as a sheep digests, having nothing to mix it with." (Agreed upon)

"Al-Halbah" with the pronunciation of the letter Haa (ح) as unpointed and the letter Baa (ب) as vowelless, and Al-Samr: are two known types of desert trees. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O Allah, make the sustenance of the family of Muhammad a sufficiency." (Agreed upon). The linguists and lexicographers said: The meaning of "sufficiency" (qūtāⁿ) is: what suffices to sustain life. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated: By Allah, except Whom there is no god, I used to lean my liver on the ground due to hunger, and I used to tie a stone to my belly due to hunger. One day, I sat on their path from which they used to go out. The Prophet, peace be upon him, passed by me and smiled when he saw me. He knew what was on my face and in my heart. Then he said: "O Aba Hurayrah!" I said: "Here I am, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Go." And he went away. I followed him. He entered and asked for permission. I was granted permission, and I entered. He found milk in a cup and said: "Where did this milk come from?" They said: "So-and-so gifted it to you." He said: "O Aba Hurayrah!" I said: "Here I am, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Go to the people of the Suffah and call them to me." He said: The people of the Suffah are the guests of Islam. They do not have families or wealth. If a gift came to him, he would send for them and share in it. This saddened me, and I said: What is this milk among the people of the Suffah! I was more deserving of a drink of this milk to strengthen myself. If they come and he orders me, then I will give it to them. And what could this milk do for me? But there was no escaping obedience to Allah and obedience to His Messenger, peace be upon him. So I went to them and called them. They came and asked for permission. They were granted permission and took their places in the house. He said: "O Aba Hurayrah!" I said: "Here I am, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Take it and give it to them." He said: So I took the cup and started giving it to a man who would drink until he was satisfied, then return the cup to me. I would give it to another who would drink until he was satisfied, then return the cup to me. Until I reached the Prophet, peace be upon him, and all the people were satisfied. He took the cup and placed it on his hand. He looked at me and smiled. He said: "O Aba Hurayrah!" I said: "Here I am, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "It is you and I left." I said: "You have spoken the truth, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Sit down and drink." So I sat down and drank. He said: "Drink." So I drank. He kept saying: "Drink" until I said: "No, by Him Who sent you with the truth, I find no way for it!" He said: "Show me." So I gave him the cup. He praised Allah Almighty, uttered His name, and drank the remainder. (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Muhammad ibn Sirin, from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I saw myself dragging myself between the pulpit of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and the chamber of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, in a state of unconsciousness. Then someone would come and place his foot on my neck, thinking I was mad, but I was not mad; I was only hungry. (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, died while his armor was mortgaged with a Jew for thirty sa's of barley. (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported: The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) pawned his coat of mail for some barley, and I went to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) with barley bread, and some rancid grease. I heard him say: "The family of Muhammad did not have a sa' of food in the morning or in the evening, and they were nine households." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I saw seventy of the people of the Suffah, and not one of them had a cloak, but rather an izar or a kisaa'. They tied it around their necks, and it reached to their shins, and some of it reached to their ankles. They would hold it with their hands, disliking that their private parts be seen. (Reported by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The bed of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was made of leather and stuffed with palm fiber. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) that he said: We were sitting with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), when a man from the Ansar came and greeted him. Then the Ansari turned to leave. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "O brother of the Ansar, how is my brother Sa'd bin Ubadah?" He said: "He is well." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Who among you will visit him?" So he got up, and we got up with him. We were a little over ten, without sandals, or shoes, or caps, or shirts, walking in that marshy land until we came to him. His people kept away from him until the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and the companions with him approached him. (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Imran ibn Husayn, may Allah be pleased with them, from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "The best of you are my generation, then those who come after them, then those who come after them." Imran said: "I do not know if the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said twice or thrice: 'Then after them will come a people who will testify without being asked for testimony, and betray without being entrusted. They will make vows and not fulfill them, and obesity will appear among them.'" (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O son of Adam: Verily, if you give what is surplus, it is better for you, and if you withhold it, it is worse for you, and you will not be blamed for what suffices, and begin with those whom you support." (Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said: a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Ubaydullah bin Muhsin Al-Ansari Al-Khatmi (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever among you wakes up secure in his household, healthy in his body, and having the provision for his day, it is as if the whole world has been gathered for him." (Reported by Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-As, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "He has succeeded who embraces Islam, and whose provision is sufficient, and whom Allah makes content with what He has given him." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Muhammad Fudalah bin Ubaid Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Tuba (glad tidings) to him who is guided to Islam, and his living is sufficient, and he is content." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and said: a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would spend consecutive nights hungry, and his family would not find dinner, and their bread was mostly barley bread. (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said: It is a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Fudhalah bin Ubaid (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when he prayed with the people, men would fall from their standing in prayer due to poverty – and they were the People of the Bench – until the bedouins would say: These are madmen. When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) finished praying, he would turn to them and say: "If you knew what you have with Allah, Almighty, you would wish that you would increase in poverty and need." (Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said it is a sound Hadith). "Al-khasasah" means extreme poverty and hunger. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Karimah Al-Miqdam bin Ma'dikarib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: "No son of Adam fills a vessel worse than his stomach. It is enough for the son of Adam to eat a few morsels that would support his back. If he must, then one-third for his food, one-third for his drink, and one-third for his breath." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, who said: It is a hasan hadith.) "Few morsels" means a few bites. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Umamah Iyās bin Tha'labah Al-Ansari Al-Harithi (may Allah be pleased with him) that the companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) mentioned the worldly life to him one day. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Do you not hear? Do you not hear? Indeed, plainness is from faith, indeed, plainness is from faith." He meant by it: ruggedness. (Narrated by Abu Dawud). "Al-Bathaathah" is with a unified ba' and two dotted dhal, and it means the shabby appearance and not wearing luxurious clothes. As for "Al-Taqahhul," it is with a qaf and a ha'. The linguists said: Al-Mutaqahhil is the man whose skin is rough from the hardship of living and abandoning luxury. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Abdullah, Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent us out and appointed Abu Ubaidah, may Allah be pleased with him, as our commander to intercept a caravan of Quraysh. He provided us with a leather bag of dates, as he found nothing else for us. Abu Ubaidah used to give us one date each. It was said to him, "How did you manage with it?" He said: "We used to suck it as a child sucks, and then drink water after it. That was enough for us for the day until night. And we used to beat the leaves of trees with our sticks, then moisten them with water and eat them." He said: "We set out along the coast of the sea, and we saw on the coast of the sea something like a huge dune. We went to it, and it was an animal called an 'Anbar. Abu Ubaidah said: 'It is dead.' Then he said: 'No, rather we are the messengers of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and in the cause of Allah, and you are in need, so eat.' We stayed there for a month, and we were three hundred, until we gained weight. And I saw us scooping fat from its eye socket with large water skins and cutting pieces of meat from it as large as a bull or the size of a bull. Abu Ubaidah took thirteen men from us and had them sit in its eye socket, and he took a rib from its ribs and set it up, then he loaded the largest camel we had with it and it passed under it. We took provisions of its meat and dried meat. When we came to Medina, we went to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and told him about that. He said: 'It is a provision that Allah brought out for you. Do you have any of its meat with you so that you can feed us?' So we sent some of it to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he ate it." (Narrated by Muslim). The "Jarāb" is a known leather container, and it is pronounced with a kasra on the jim and a fatha on it, and the kasra is more eloquent. His saying: "Namassuhā" is with a fatha on the mim. "Al-Khabt" are known tree leaves that camels eat. "Al-Kathīb" is a sand dune. "Al-Waqb" with a fatha on the waw and sukoon on the qaf and then a baa, which is the socket of the eye. "Bi-takhfīf al-ḥā": meaning he put the saddle on it. "Al-Sha'iq" with the pronounced sheen and qaf: is the meat that is cut to be dried, and Allah knows best. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Asma bint Yazid, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The sleeves of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, reached the wrist. (Narrated by Abu Dawud and At-Tirmidhi, who said: It is a hasan hadith). "Ar-Rusgh (with Sad) and Ar-Risgh (with Sin) both mean the joint between the palm and the forearm." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) reported: We were digging the trench on the day of the battle of the Trench, when we came across a hard rock which the pickaxe could not break. They came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: "Here is a rock that has appeared in the trench." He said: "I will descend." Then he stood up, and his stomach was bound with a stone. We had stayed for three days without tasting anything. Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) took the pickaxe, struck it, and it turned into a heap of soft sand. I said: "O Messenger of Allah, permit me to go to the house." I said to my wife: "I have seen something with the Prophet (peace be upon him) that I cannot endure. Do you have anything?" She said: "I have barley and a young goat." So I slaughtered the young goat and ground the barley, until we put the meat in the pot. Then I came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) when the dough had risen and the pot was almost cooked on the hearth. I said: "I have some food. Come, O Messenger of Allah, with one or two men." He asked: "How much is it?" I told him, and he said: "Much and good. Tell her not to take the pot off the fire, nor the bread out of the oven until I come." Then he said: "Get up!" So the Emigrants and the Helpers got up. I went to my wife and said: "Woe to you! The Prophet (peace be upon him), the Emigrants, the Helpers, and those with them have come!" She asked: "Did he ask you?" I said: "Yes." He said: "Enter, and do not crowd." He began to break the bread and put the meat on it, and covered the pot and the oven when he took from it, and brought it to his companions, then he took it away. He kept breaking and scooping until they were all satisfied, and there was still some left. He said: "Eat this and send some as a gift, for the people have been afflicted by famine." (Agreed upon)

In another narration, Jabir said: When the trench was dug, I saw the Prophet (peace be upon him) hungry. I went to my wife and said: "Do you have anything? For I have seen the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) extremely hungry." She brought out a bag containing a Sa' of barley, and we had a domesticated goat. I slaughtered it and ground the barley. When I finished, I prepared it in her pot. Then I went to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). She said: "Do not disgrace me with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and those with him." I came to him and whispered to him, saying: "O Messenger of Allah, we have slaughtered a goat, and I have ground a Sa' of barley. Come with a few men with you." The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) called out and said: "O people of the trench, Jabir has prepared some food, so come!" The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Do not take your pot off the fire, nor bake your dough until I come." I came, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) came leading the people. When I came to my wife, she said: "You and you!" I said: "I have done as you said." She brought out the dough and spat into it and blessed it. Then he went to our pot and spat into it and blessed it. Then he said: "Call a baker to bake with you, and scoop from your pot and do not take it off." They were a thousand. I swear by Allah, they ate until they left it and turned away, and our pot was still bubbling as it was, and our dough was still baking as it was.

"A hard rock" means a thick, hard piece of earth that the pickaxe cannot work. "Heap" originally means a sand dune, but here it means soft soil, which is the meaning of "Aheyl." "Hearthstones" are the stones on which the pot is placed. "Crowded" means to push and shove. "Famine" means hunger. "Hunger" (khams) means hunger. "I turned back" means I turned and returned. "Beast" (bahima) is a diminutive of bahma, which is a young goat. "Domesticated" is that which is accustomed to the house. "Su'ur" is the food to which people are invited, and it is in Persian. "Hayyala" means come. And her saying "You and you!" means she argued with him and cursed him, because she thought that what she had would not be enough for them, so she was ashamed and it was hidden from her what Allah Almighty honored His Prophet (peace be upon him) with, this apparent miracle and evident sign. "Basaqa" means to spit; and it is also said "bazaga" - three languages. "He intended" means he meant. "Scoop" means to scoop, and a scoop is a ladle. "It was bubbling" means it made a sound of boiling, and Allah knows best. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that Abu Talha said to Umm Sulaim: "I have heard the voice of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) weakened, and I recognize hunger in it. Do you have anything?" She said: "Yes." So she brought out some barley cakes, then took her head covering, wrapped some of the bread in it, and put it under my garment and covered me with some of it, then sent me to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). I went with it, and I found the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sitting in the mosque with people. I stood before them, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to me: 'Is Abu Talha who sent you?' I said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Is it food?' I said: 'Yes.' The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Get up.' So they went ahead of me until I came to Abu Talha and informed him. Abu Talha said: 'O Umm Sulaim, the Messenger of Allah has come with the people, and we have nothing to feed them?' She said: 'Allah and His Messenger know best.' Abu Talha went until he met the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) came with him until they entered. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Bring what you have, O Umm Sulaim.' She brought that bread, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) ordered it to be broken, and Umm Sulaim squeezed a skin of ghee on it, and it became like a sauce. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said what Allah willed him to say in it, then he said: 'Admit ten.' So they were admitted, and they ate until they were satisfied, then they left. Then he said: 'Admit ten.' So they were admitted, and they ate until they were satisfied, then they left. Then he said: 'Admit ten.' So they were admitted until all the people ate and were satisfied, and the people were seventy men or eighty." (Agreed upon). In one narration: "So ten kept entering and ten kept leaving until no one among them remained but that he entered and ate until he was satisfied. Then she prepared it, and it was as it was when they ate from it." In another narration: "So they ate ten by ten until he did that for eighty men, then the Prophet (peace be upon him) ate afterwards and the people of the house, and they left some leftover." In another narration: "Then they gave their neighbors the surplus." In another narration from Anas, he said: "I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) one day and found him sitting with his companions, with a band tied around his stomach. I said to some of his companions: 'Why is the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) wearing a band around his stomach?' They said: 'From hunger.' So I went to Abu Talha, who was the husband of Umm Sulaim bint Milhan, and I said: 'O father, I have seen the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) with a band around his stomach. I asked some of his companions, and they said: 'From hunger.' So Abu Talha went to my mother and said: 'Is there anything?' She said: 'Yes, I have some broken pieces of bread and dates. If the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) comes alone, we can feed him, but if others come with him, it will be insufficient for them.' And he mentioned the rest of the Hadith." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Richness is not in the abundance of worldly goods, but richness is in the richness of the soul." (Agreed upon). "Al-'Ard" with fath al-'ayn and al-ra' means wealth. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "He has succeeded who embraces Islam, and is provided with a sufficiency, and Allah makes him content with what He has given him." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Hakim bin Hizam (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that he asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) for something, and he gave it to him. He asked again, and he gave it to him. He asked a third time, and he gave it to him. Then he said, "O Hakim, this wealth is sweet and green. Whoever takes it with a generous heart will be blessed in it, and whoever takes it with a greedy heart will not be blessed in it, and he will be like one who eats but is not satisfied. The upper hand is better than the lower hand." Hakim said, "O Messenger of Allah, by the One who sent you with the truth, I will not ask anyone for anything after you until I leave this world." Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) used to invite Hakim to give him something, but he refused to accept anything from him. Then Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) invited him to give him something, and he refused to accept it. Umar said, "O Muslims, I bear witness to Hakim that I offer him his right which Allah has allotted to him from this booty, and he refuses to take it." Hakim did not ask anyone for anything after the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) until he passed away. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated by Abu Burda from Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We went out with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) on an expedition. We were six men sharing one camel, taking turns to ride it. Our feet became blistered, and my toenails fell off. We wrapped rags around our feet. This expedition was named Dhat Ar-Riqaa' (The ذات الرقاع) because of the rags we wrapped around our feet. Abu Burda said: Abu Musa narrated this Hadith, then he disliked it and said: I wish I had not mentioned it. He seemed to dislike mentioning something of his deeds. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Amr bin Taghlab - with a fathah on the thaa' and a sukoon on the ghayn and a kasrah on the laam - may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was brought wealth or captives, and he distributed them. He gave to some men and left others. It reached him that those whom he left were displeased. So he praised Allah, then he extolled Him, then he said: "Indeed, by Allah, I give to a man and I leave a man, and the one whom I leave is more beloved to me than the one whom I give. But I only give to some people because of what I see in their hearts of anxiety and panic, and I entrust others to what Allah has placed in their hearts of contentment and goodness, including Amr bin Taghlab." Amr bin Taghlab said: "By Allah, I would not wish for myself, in exchange for the words of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, the red camels (Narrated by Bukhari). 'Al-hal' (panic) is the most intense anxiety, and it is said to be impatience." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Hakim bin Hizam (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The upper hand is better than the lower hand, and begin with those whom you support. The best charity is that which is given from a state of sufficiency. Whoever seeks to remain chaste, Allah will make him chaste. And whoever seeks to be self-sufficient, Allah will make him self-sufficient." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sufyan Sakhr bin Harb, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not insist excessively in asking. By Allah, if any one of you asks me for something, and his request is granted by me, while I dislike it, then that which is given to him will not be blessed." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Abdur-Rahman Auf bin Malik Al-Ashja'i, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, nine or eight or seven. He said: "Will you not pledge allegiance to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him?" And we had recently pledged allegiance. So we said: "We have already pledged allegiance to you, O Messenger of Allah, so what do we pledge allegiance for?" He said: "That you worship Allah and associate nothing with Him, and the five prayers, and obey." And he whispered a hidden phrase: "And do not ask people for anything." So I saw some of those men, if one of them dropped his whip, he would not ask anyone to hand it to him. (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "One will continue to ask others until he meets Allah, and there will be no flesh on his face." (Agreed upon). "Maz'ah" with a damma on the meem, sukoon on the zaa, and an unpointed ain: a piece. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said while on the pulpit, and he mentioned charity and abstaining from begging: "The upper hand is better than the lower hand. The upper hand is the one that gives, and the lower hand is the one that asks." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever begs from people to increase his wealth, is asking for embers. So let him ask for a little or a lot." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Samra bin Jundab, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Begging is a scratch that a man scratches his face with, except that a man begs from a ruler or in a matter of necessity." (Narrated by Tirmidhi, and he said: a hasan sahih hadith). "Al-kadd" means: scratching and the like. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever is afflicted by poverty and complains about it to people will not have his poverty alleviated. Whoever complains about it to Allah, Allah will soon provide him with sustenance, whether immediate or delayed." (Reported by Abu Dawud and At-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan hadith). "Yushiku" (يوشك) with a kasra on the "ya" means "he hastens". [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Thawban, may Allah be pleased with him, it is reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Who will guarantee me that he will not ask from people anything, and I will guarantee him Paradise?" I said: "I will." So he (Thawban) never asked anyone for anything. (Reported by Abu Dawud with a sound chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Abu Bishr Qubaisa bin Al-Mukhariq (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I undertook a debt for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and asked him for it. He said: "Wait until the charity reaches us, and we will order it for you." Then he said: "O Qubaisa, begging is only lawful for one of three people: a man who undertakes a debt, so begging is lawful for him until he gets it, and then he refrains. And a man who is afflicted by a disaster that wipes out his wealth, so begging is lawful for him until he gets enough to live on, or he said: enough to sustain himself. And a man who is afflicted by poverty, until three men of understanding from his people say: So-and-so has been afflicted by poverty, so begging is lawful for him until he gets enough to live on, or he said: enough to sustain himself. Any other form of begging, O Qubaisa, is unlawful and consumes its owner unlawfully." (Narrated by Muslim). "Al-Himalah" (with the opening of the ha) means that a fight or something similar occurs between two groups, and a person reconciles them for a sum of money that he undertakes and commits himself to. "Al-Ja'iha" is a calamity that befalls a person's wealth. "Al-Qawam" (with the kasra or fatha of the qaf) is what sustains a person's affairs from wealth and the like. "As-Sadad" (with the kasra of the sin) is what meets the need of the needy and suffices him, and "Al-Faqr" is poverty. "Al-Hija" is intellect. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The poor is not he who goes around to people, who is repelled by a morsel or two, and a date or two. Rather, the poor is he who does not find enough to suffice him, and he is not noticed so that he is given charity, and he does not stand and ask people." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Salim bin Abdullah bin Umar, from his father Abdullah bin Umar, from Umar (may Allah be pleased with them), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to give me a stipend. I would say: Give it to someone poorer than me. He said: "Take it. If something from this wealth comes to you, and you are neither seeking it nor asking for it, then take it and use it as you wish, either all of it or some of it, and if not, do not let your heart follow it." Salim said: Abdullah did not ask anyone for anything, nor did he refuse anything he was given. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Abu Abdullah Al-Zubayr bin Al-Awwam, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "For one of you to take his rope, go to the mountain, and bring a bundle of firewood on his back and sell it, and thus Allah shields his face from needing to beg, is better for him than asking people, whether they give him or withhold from him." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "For one of you to gather a bundle of firewood on his back is better for him than to ask someone, so they give him or refuse him." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
And from him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "David, peace be upon him, used to eat only from the labor of his hand." (Reported by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
And from him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Zechariah, peace be upon him, was a carpenter." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Al-Miqdam bin Ma'd Yakrib, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "No one has ever eaten better food than that which he eats from the work of his own hand, and the Prophet of Allah, David, peace be upon him, used to eat from the work of his own hand." (Bukhari narrated it). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "There is no envy except in two cases: a man whom Allah has given wealth and he spends it in the cause of truth, and a man whom Allah has given wisdom and he judges by it and teaches it." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him it is narrated, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Which of you likes the wealth of his heir more than his own wealth?" They said: O Messenger of Allah, there is no one among us except that his own wealth is more beloved to him. He said: "Indeed, his wealth is what he sent forth, and the wealth of his heir is what he left behind." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
And from Adi bin Hatim (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) said: "Fear the Fire even if it is by half a date." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was never asked for anything and said: No. (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There is no day in the morning for the servants except that two angels descend. One of them says: 'O Allah, give to the one who spends,' and the other says: 'O Allah, give to the one who withholds destruction.'" (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah the Almighty said: Spend, O son of Adam, and I will spend on you." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-'As (may Allah be pleased with them both) that a man asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him): "Which Islam is best?" He said: "To feed people, and to greet those whom you know and those whom you do not know." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Forty deeds, the highest of which is giving a goat for milk. No one performs one of these deeds hoping for its reward and believing in its promise, except that Allah the Almighty will admit him to Paradise by it." (Narrated by Bukhari. This hadith has been previously explained in the chapter on explaining the abundance of ways of doing good.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Umamah Suday bin 'Ajlan (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O son of Adam, if you give away what is beyond your need, it is better for you. If you withhold it, it is worse for you. You will not be blamed for having enough. Start with those whom you support, and the upper hand is better than the lower hand." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was never asked for anything in Islam but that he gave it. A man came to him and he gave him sheep between two mountains. The man returned to his people and said: "O my people, embrace Islam, for Muhammad gives without fear of poverty. And indeed, a man would embrace Islam not wanting but the worldly life, but soon Islam would become more beloved to him than the world and all that it contains." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) distributed a distribution, and I said: "O Messenger of Allah, those who are more deserving of it than them were more entitled to it?" He said: "They gave me a choice, either to ask me for something improper and I give them, or to be stingy with them, and I am not stingy." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated by Jubayr bin Mut'im (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: While he was walking with the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) on his return from Hunayn, the Bedouins surrounded him asking for alms, until they compelled him to go to a thorny tree, and they snatched his cloak. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) stopped and said: "Give me back my cloak! If I had as many cattle as these thorny trees, I would distribute them among you, and then you would not find me stingy, nor a liar, nor a coward." (Reported by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Charity does not decrease wealth, and Allah does not increase a servant's forgiveness except in honor, and no one humbles himself to Allah except that Allah raises him in status." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated from Abu Kabshah 'Amr bin Sa'd al-Anmari (may Allah be pleased with him) that he heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: "I swear by three things, and I will tell you a Hadith, so preserve it: No charity ever decreased the wealth of a servant, and no servant who is wronged and endures it patiently, but Allah will increase his honor, and no servant opens the door of begging, but Allah opens for him the door of poverty, or a similar statement. And I will tell you a Hadith, so preserve it: Verily, the world is for four types of people: a servant whom Allah has provided with wealth and knowledge, so he fears his Lord with it, and maintains his kinship ties, and knows that Allah has a right in it. This one is of the best ranks. And a servant whom Allah has provided with knowledge, but not with wealth, he has a sincere intention and says: If I had wealth, I would do the deeds of so-and-so. So he is (rewarded) according to his intention, and their reward is equal. And a servant whom Allah has provided with wealth, but not with knowledge, he acts foolishly with his wealth without knowledge, he does not fear his Lord with it, nor does he maintain his kinship ties, nor does he know that Allah has a right in it. This one is of the worst ranks. And a servant whom Allah has not provided with wealth nor knowledge, he says: If I had wealth, I would do the deeds of so-and-so with it. So he is (burdened) according to his intention, and their burden is equal." (Tirmidhi said: A Hasan Sahih Hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that they slaughtered a sheep, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "What is left of it?" She said: Nothing is left of it but its shoulder. He said: "It is all left except its shoulder." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and said: It is a saheeh hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Asma bint Abi Bakr (may Allah be pleased with them both) she said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to me: "Do not hoard, lest you be hoarded against." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Huraira, may God be pleased with him, that he heard the Messenger of God, may God's peace and blessings be upon him, say: "The parable of the miser and the spender is like two men wearing two shirts of iron from their chests to their collarbones. As for the spender, he does not spend but that it becomes wide, or covers his skin until it hides his fingertips and erases his footprints. As for the miser, he does not want to spend anything but that every ring sticks to its place, so he tries to widen it but it does not widen." (Agreed upon). And "al-Jannah" means armor. And the meaning is that the spender, whenever he spends, it becomes wide and long until it trails behind him and hides his feet and the imprint of his steps and his strides. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever gives a date as charity from lawful earnings, and Allah does not accept anything but that which is lawful, then Allah accepts it with His right hand, and then He nurtures it for its owner just as one of you nurtures his foal until it becomes like a mountain." (Agreed upon) "Al-Falu" is with a fathah on the faa, a dammah on the laam, and a shaddah on the waw, and it is also said: with a kasrah on the faa, a sukoon on the laam, and a light waw: and it is the foal. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "While a man was walking in a desolate land, he heard a voice in a cloud saying: 'Water so-and-so's garden.' So that cloud moved aside and poured its water on a lava field. And behold, a stream from those streams had absorbed all that water. So he followed the water, and behold, a man standing in his garden, directing the water with his spade. So he said to him: 'O servant of Allah, what is your name?' He said: 'So-and-so,' the name that he heard in the cloud. So he said to him: 'O servant of Allah, why do you ask me about my name?' He said: 'I heard a voice in the cloud whose water this is, saying: "Water so-and-so's garden," and that is your name. So what do you do with it?' He said: 'Since you have said that, I look at what comes out of it, and I give a third of it in charity, and I and my family eat a third, and I return a third of it to it.' (Narrated by Muslim). 'Al-Harrāh' is land covered with black stones. 'And Al-Sharjah,' with an open shīn, a silent rā, and a jīm, is a watercourse." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Beware of injustice, for injustice is darkness on the Day of Resurrection, and beware of greed, for greed destroyed those before you. It drove them to shed each other's blood and to violate what was sacred to them." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: A man came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: "I am in distress." So he sent to some of his wives, and one said: "By Him Who has sent you with truth, I have nothing but water." Then he sent to another, and she said the same thing, until they all said the same thing: "No, by Him Who has sent you with truth, I have nothing but water." Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Who will host him tonight?" A man from the Ansar said: "I, O Messenger of Allah." So he took him to his home, and said to his wife: "Honor the guest of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)." In another narration, he said to his wife: "Do you have anything?" She said: "No, except the food of my children." He said: "Then prepare something for them. And when they want to eat dinner, put them to sleep. And when our guest comes, extinguish the lamp and let him think that we are eating." So they sat down and the guest ate, and they spent the night hungry. When morning came, he went to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: "Allah has admired your actions with your guest tonight." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The food of two is enough for three, and the food of three is enough for four." (Agreed upon). And in a narration of Muslim from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: The food of one is enough for two, and the food of two is enough for four, and the food of four is enough for eight. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, who said: While we were on a journey with the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, a man came on a riding animal. He began to look to his right and left. Then the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever has a surplus riding animal, let him give it to one who has no riding animal, and whoever has a surplus of provisions, let him give it to one who has no provisions." He mentioned kinds of wealth until we saw that none of us had a right to any surplus. (Reported by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sahl bin Sa'd (may Allah be pleased with him) that a woman came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with a woven cloak and said: "I have woven it to clothe you with it." The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) took it, needing it. He went out to us, and it was his lower garment. So, so-and-so said: "Clothe me with it, how fine it is!" He said: "Yes." The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sat in the gathering, then he returned, folded it, and sent it to him. The people said to him: "You did not do well! The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) wore it when he needed it, then you asked for it, knowing that he does not refuse a beggar." He said: "By Allah, I did not ask for it to wear it, but I asked for it to be my shroud." Sahl said: "And it was his shroud." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If the Ash'arites run out of provisions during a campaign, or their families' food is scarce in Medina, they gather what they have in one cloth and divide it among themselves from one vessel equally. They are of me and I am of them." (Agreed upon). "Ran out of provisions" means their provisions were finished or nearly finished. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sahl bin Sa'd (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was brought a drink, and he drank from it. To his right was a boy, and to his left were the elders. He said to the boy: "Will you permit me to give this to these people?" The boy said: "No, by Allah, O Messenger of Allah, I would not prefer anyone over you from you." So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) put it in his hand. (Agreed upon). "Talahu" with the dot on top, meaning "he put it". And this boy was Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "While Ayyub, peace be upon him, was bathing naked, a swarm of locusts made of gold fell upon him. Ayyub began to gather them into his garment, and his Lord, Glorified and Exalted, called to him, 'O Ayyub, was I not sufficient for you from that which you see?' He said, 'Yes, by Your glory, but I cannot do without Your blessing.' (Reported by Bukhari)." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no envy except in two cases: a man whom Allah has given wealth and he spends it in the right way, and a man whom Allah has given wisdom and he judges by it and teaches it." (Agreed upon and its explanation was previously given). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) who said: "There is no envy except in two cases: a man whom Allah has given the Qur'an, and he recites it day and night, and a man whom Allah has given wealth, and he spends it day and night." (Agreed upon) "Al-Inaa": hours. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the poor emigrants came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, and said: "The wealthy have gone with the highest ranks and everlasting bliss." He said: "And what is that?" They said: "They pray as we pray, and they fast as we fast, and they give charity and we do not give charity, and they emancipate slaves and we do not emancipate slaves." The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Shall I not teach you something by which you can overtake those who have preceded you and overtake those who will come after you, and no one will be better than you except one who does the same as you did?" They said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "You say 'Subhan Allah', 'Allahu Akbar', and 'Alhamdulillah' thirty-three times after each prayer." The poor emigrants returned to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, and said: "Our wealthy brothers heard what we did and they did the same." The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "That is the bounty of Allah, He gives it to whom He wills." (Agreed upon). This is the wording of the narration of Muslim. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) reported: Allah's Messenger (peace be upon him) took me by the shoulder and said, "Be in this world as though you were a stranger or a traveler." Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) used to say, "When you wake up in the morning, do not wait for the evening, and when you go to sleep in the evening, do not wait for the morning. Take advantage of your health before you fall sick, and of your life before your death." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "It is not befitting for a Muslim who has something to bequeath to spend two nights except that his will is written with him." (Agreed upon) This is the wording of Al-Bukhari. And in a narration of Muslim: "spend three nights." Ibn Umar said: "No night has passed since I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say that, except that I had my will with me." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, drew lines and said: "This is the human, and this is his appointed time. While he is like that, the closer line came." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) drew a square and drew a line in the middle extending out of it, and he drew small lines towards the line in the middle from its side that was in the middle. He said: "This is man, and this is his appointed term surrounding him - or it has surrounded him - and this is his hope extending beyond it, and these small lines are the calamities. If this misses him, that one will bite him, and if that one misses him, this one will bite him." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Hasten to do good deeds before seven things: do you await but poverty that makes you forget, or wealth that makes you arrogant, or a sickness that corrupts, or old age that makes you senile, or death that dispatches suddenly, or the Dajjal, for he is the worst of what is to come, or the Hour, and the Hour is more bitter and more dreadful?" (Tirmidhi narrated it and said it is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him it is narrated, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Remember often that which destroys pleasures" (meaning death). (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said it is a Hasan Hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ubayy bin Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, when a third of the night had passed, would stand and say: "O people, remember Allah, the Shaker has come, followed by the Shaken. Death has come with what it contains, death has come with what it contains." I said: "O Messenger of Allah, I often send blessings upon you, so how much of my prayers should I dedicate to you?" He said: "Whatever you wish." I said: "A quarter?" He said: "Whatever you wish, and if you increase, it is for you." I said: "Then half?" He said: "Whatever you wish, and if you increase, it is for you." I said: "Then two-thirds?" He said: "Whatever you wish, and if you increase, it is better for you." I said: "Should I dedicate all of my prayers to you?" He said: "Then your worries will be sufficient, and your sins will be forgiven." (Narrated by Tirmidhi and he said: It is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Buraydah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "I had forbidden you to visit the graves, but now you may visit them." (Narrated by Muslim). And in another narration: "Whoever wishes to visit the graves, let him visit them, for they remind us of the Hereafter." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would go out at the end of the night, on her turn, to Al-Baqi'. He would say: "Peace be upon you, O believing people, and may that which was promised to you come to pass. Tomorrow you shall be delayed, and we, if Allah wills, shall soon join you. O Allah, forgive the people of Al-Baqi' Al-Gharqad." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Buraydah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: When the Prophet (peace be upon him) would go out to the graves, he would teach them to say: "Peace be upon you, dwellers of this abode, of the believers and the Muslims. We, God willing, will join you. I ask Allah for well-being for us and for you." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: Allah's Messenger, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, passed by some graves in Medina and turned his face towards them and said: "Peace be upon you, O dwellers of the graves. May Allah forgive us and you. You are our predecessors, and we are following in your footsteps." (Reported by Tirmidhi and he said: Hadith hasan). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Let none of you wish for death. If he is a doer of good, he may increase in his good deeds, and if he is a doer of evil, he may seek to turn back from his evil." (Agreed upon). This is the wording of Bukhari. In a narration by Muslim from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) he said: "Let none of you wish for death, nor pray for it before it comes to him, for when he dies, his deeds are cut off, and a believer's life only increases his good." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "None of you should wish for death due to some harm that has befallen him. If he must do so, then he should say: 'O Allah, keep me alive as long as life is better for me, and take me away when death is better for me.'" (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Qais bin Abi Hazim, who said: We visited Khabbab bin Al-Aratt, may Allah be pleased with him, as he was ill, and he had been cauterized seven times. He said: "Our companions who passed before us, their worldly lives did not diminish them, and we have obtained so much that we can find no place for it except in the earth. And were it not that the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade us from wishing for death, I would have wished for it." Then we visited him again, and he was building a wall for himself. He said: "A Muslim is rewarded for everything he spends, except for something he puts into this earth." (Agreed upon, and this is the wording of the narration of Al-Bukhari.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from An-Nu'man bin Bashir (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) say: "Indeed, what is lawful is clear, and what is unlawful is clear, and between them are matters which are doubtful, known to few people. So, whoever guards against doubtful matters, he has absolved himself for his religion and his honor. And whoever falls into doubtful matters, he has fallen into what is unlawful. It is like a shepherd who grazes around a protected area, and he is liable to enter it. Behold, every king has a protected area, and behold, Allah's protected area is His prohibitions. Behold, in the body there is a morsel of flesh, if it is good, the whole body is good, and if it is corrupt, the whole body is corrupt. Behold, it is the heart." (Agreed upon. And they narrated it through several chains of transmission with similar wording). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Prophet (peace be upon him) found a date on the road and said, "Were it not that I fear it might be from the charity, I would have eaten it." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from An-Nawwas bin Sam'an (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: "Righteousness is good character, and sin is that which wavers within your soul, and which you would hate for people to know about." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Wabisa bin Ma'bad, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and he said: "You have come to ask about righteousness?" I said: Yes. He said: "Seek a ruling from your heart. Righteousness is what the soul finds peace in, and what the heart is at ease with. And sin is what causes disquiet in the soul and hesitation in the chest, even if people give you their verdicts." (A hasan hadith, narrated by Ahmad and Ad-Darimi in their Musnads.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sur'ah - with a dammah on the "seen" and a fatha on the "raa" - Uqbah ibn Al-Harith, may Allah be pleased with him, that he married the daughter of Abu Ihab ibn Azizi. A woman came to him and said: "Indeed, I have suckled Uqbah and the one he married." Uqbah said to her: "I do not know that you have suckled me, nor did you inform me." So he rode to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in Medina and asked him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "How, when it has been said?" So Uqbah divorced her, and she married another husband. (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Al-Hasan bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: I memorized from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "Leave that which makes you doubt for that which does not make you doubt." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her), she said: Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) had a slave who brought him tribute. Abu Bakr used to eat from his tribute. One day, the slave brought something, and Abu Bakr ate from it. The slave said to him: "Do you know what this is?" Abu Bakr said: "What is it?" He said: "I practiced soothsaying for a man in the days of ignorance, and I am not good at soothsaying except that I deceived him. He met me and gave me this for it, from which you ate." So Abu Bakr put his hand in his stomach and vomited everything that was in his stomach. (Narrated by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Nafi' that 'Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) had allotted four thousand to the early emigrants and allotted three thousand five hundred to his son. It was said to him: "He is among the emigrants, so why did you deduct from him?" He said: "His father emigrated with him, meaning: he is not like one who emigrated by himself." (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Attiyah bin Uruwah Al-Sa'di, the companion, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A servant will not reach the level of the God-fearing until he abandons what is permissible out of fear of what is impermissible." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said: It is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Indeed, Allah loves the pious, self-sufficient, and hidden servant." (Narrated by Muslim). And what is meant by "self-sufficient" is contentment of the soul, as stated previously in a sound hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Sa'eed al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) that a man said: "O Messenger of Allah, which of the people is best?" He said: "A believer who strives with himself and his wealth in the cause of Allah." He said: "Then who?" He said: "A man who withdraws to a mountain pass and worships his Lord." And in one narration: "He fears Allah and keeps the people safe from his evil." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, may God be pleased with him, it is narrated that the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Soon the best wealth of a Muslim will be sheep, with which he will follow the heights of the mountains and the places where rain falls, fleeing with his religion from tribulations." (Narrated by Bukhari). And "sha'af al-jibal" means its heights. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "Allah did not send any prophet except that he herded sheep." His companions said: "And you?" He said: "I used to herd them for qirats for the people of Makkah." (Reported by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "The best of people's livelihood is a man who holds the reins of his horse in the cause of Allah, flying on its back, whenever he hears a call for help or a cry for alarm, he flies on it, seeking to inflict death, or death in its likely places, or a man who is with his flock on a mountain peak of these peaks, or in the hollow of a valley of these valleys, he establishes prayer, pays zakat, and worships his Lord until certainty (death) comes to him. No one among the people is except in goodness." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Iyad bin Himar, may God be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, God has inspired me to be humble so that no one may boast over another, and no one may oppress another." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Charity does not decrease wealth, and no one forgives another except that Allah increases him in honor, and no one humbles himself to Allah except that Allah raises him." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) that he passed by some children and greeted them, saying: "The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to do this." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
