Then another passed by, and the deceased was praised. Umar said: "It is obligatory." Then a third passed by, and the deceased was spoken ill of. Umar said: "It is obligatory." Abu Al-Aswad said: I asked, "What is obligatory, O Commander of the Faithful?" He replied: "I said as the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: 'Any Muslim who is testified to by four (people) for good, Allah will admit him to Paradise.' We said: 'And three?' He said: 'And three.' We said: 'And two?' He said: 'And two.' Then we did not ask him about one." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "No Muslim who has lost three children who had not reached the age of accountability will be admitted to Paradise by Allah except through His mercy towards them." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "No Muslim has three children die, but that the Fire will not touch him except as an expiation for an oath." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Saeed Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A woman came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: "O Messenger of Allah, the men have taken your hadith, so set aside a day for us from yourself, on which we can come to you and you can teach us what Allah has taught you." He said: "Gather on such and such a day." So they gathered, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) came to them and taught them what Allah had taught him. Then he said: "No woman among you presents three of her children except that they will be a shield for her from the Fire." A woman said: "And two?" The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "And two." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to his companions - meaning when they reached Al-Hijr: the dwellings of Thamud: "Do not enter upon these punished people unless you are weeping, and if you are not weeping, then do not enter upon them, lest what befell them befall you." (Agreed upon) And in a narration, he said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed by Al-Hijr, he said: "Do not enter the dwellings of those who wronged themselves, lest what befell them befall you, unless you are weeping." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) covered his head and hastened his pace until he crossed the valley. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Ka'b bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, went out on the expedition of Tabuk on Thursday, and he liked to go out on Thursday. (Agreed upon). And in a narration in "Sahihayn": For rarely did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, go out except on Thursday. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sakhr bin Wuda'a al-Ghamdi, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O Allah, bless my Ummah in their early morning." And when he sent out a detachment or an army, he would send them out at the beginning of the day. Sakhr was a merchant, and he would send out his trade at the beginning of the day, so he became wealthy and his money increased. (Narrated by Abu Dawood and Tirmidhi, who said: It is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If people knew what I know about being alone, no rider would travel by night alone." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Umar ibn Shu'ayb, from his father, from his grandfather, may Allah be pleased with them, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The rider is a devil, and two riders are two devils, and three are a company of riders." (Narrated by Abu Dawud, At-Tirmidhi, and An-Nasa'i with authentic chains of narration, and At-Tirmidhi said: A hadith hasan.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'eed and Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with them, they said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When three go on a journey, let them appoint one of them as their leader." A hasan hadith. (Reported by Abu Dawud with a hasan chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "The best of companions are four, and the best of detachments are four hundred, and the best of armies are four thousand, and twelve thousand will not be overcome due to scarcity." (Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Tirmidhi, who said: A hasan hadith) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "When you travel in fertile land, give the camels their share of the land (i.e., let them graze). When you travel in arid land, make them travel swiftly and spare their marrow. And when you camp at night, avoid the road, for the roads are the paths of animals and the dwelling places of vermin at night." (Narrated by Muslim).

Meaning: "give the camels their share of the land" means: be gentle with them in your travel so they can graze while moving. And his saying: "nakiyaha" (نقيها), which is with a kasrah on the nun, sukun on the qaf, and a yaa with two dots below it, means: the marrow. This means: travel swiftly with them until you reach your destination before their marrow is depleted due to the hardship of travel. And "al-ta'rees" (التعريس) means: camping at night. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Qatadah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was on a journey and camped at night, he would lie on his right side. If he camped before dawn, he would prop his arm and rest his head on his palm. (Narrated by Muslim). The scholars said: He propped his arm so that he would not be overcome by sleep, and miss the prayer of Fajr beyond its time or the beginning of its time. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Keep to traveling at night, for the earth is folded up at night." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a Hasan chain of narration). Traveling at night is to travel by night. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Tha'labah Al-Khashani, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: When people descended to a stopping place, they would scatter in the ravines and valleys. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Your scattering in these ravines and valleys is only from Satan!" So after that, they did not descend to a stopping place except that they gathered together. (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a Hasan chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sahl bin Amr - and it was said Sahl bin Al-Rabi' bin Amr Al-Ansari, known as Ibn Al-Hanzaliyyah, and he was from the people of Bay'ah Ar-Ridwan, may Allah be pleased with him - that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by a camel whose back had become sunken to its belly. He said: "Fear Allah regarding these dumb animals. Ride them in goodness and eat them in goodness." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a sound chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Ja'far Abdullah bin Ja'far, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, once rode me behind him and whispered to me a hadith that I would not tell anyone. And the most preferred thing the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to conceal himself behind for his needs was a mound or a palm grove. Meaning: a palm wall. (Narrated like this, abbreviated). Al-Barqani added with the chain of narration of Muslim after the words: a palm grove: So he entered a grove belonging to a man from the Ansar, and there was a camel in it. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saw it, it rumbled and its eyes shed tears. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, approached it, and wiped its hump and the part behind its ears, and it calmed down. He said: "Whose camel is this? To whom does this camel belong?" A young man from the Ansar came and said: "It is mine, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Will you not fear Allah concerning this animal whom Allah has given you dominion over? For it complains to me that you starve it and tire it." (Narrated by Abu Dawood, like the narration of Al-Barqani). His saying: "dhafrah" (ذفراه) and it is with a kasra on the dhal, and sukun on the fa, and it is a feminine singular word. The linguists said: Al-dhifra is the place where the camel sweats behind the ear. And his saying: "tad'abuhu" (تدئبه) meaning: you tire it. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: "When we would descend to a stopping place, we would not pray until we had unloaded our baggage." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a chain of narration meeting Muslim's criteria). And his saying: "we would not pray" means we would not pray the voluntary prayer, and its meaning is: although we were eager for prayer, we would not offer it before unloading the baggage and resting the mounts. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: While we were on a journey, a man came on his mount, and he began to look to his right and left. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever has an extra mount, let him give it to one who has no mount, and whoever has extra provisions, let him give them to one who has no provisions." He then mentioned categories of wealth as he mentioned them, until we thought that none of us had any right to any surplus. (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he intended to go on an expedition, so he said: "O company of Emigrants and Helpers! Some of your brothers have no wealth or kin. Let one of you take two or three men with him. For none of us has a mount to carry him except for a single saddle-beast, meaning one of them." He said: "So I took two or three men with me, and my wealth, except for a single saddle-beast, which was like one of theirs, from my camel." (Reported by Abu Dawud) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to fall behind on the journey, urging on the weak and riding behind them, and praying for them. (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a good chain of narration.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn `Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when he mounted his camel to go out on a journey, he would say "Allahu Akbar" three times, then he would say: "Glory be to Him Who has subjected this to us, and we could never have subjected it. And to our Lord we shall surely return. O Allah, we ask You on this journey of ours to be righteous and God-fearing, and to do deeds that please You. O Allah, make this journey easy for us and let its distance be short. O Allah, You are the Companion on the journey and the Successor to the family. O Allah, I seek refuge in You from the hardships of travel, the sorrow of the view, and the evil outcome in family and property." When he returned, he would say these words and add to them: "We are returning, repenting, worshipping, praising our Lord." (Narrated by Muslim). "Muqtarinin" means "able to bear." "Wa`thaa'" with fathah on the waw and sukun on the `ayn, and with thaa' and lengthened, means "hardship." "Kaa'bah" with lengthening means "a change in the soul due to grief or the like." "Munqalab" means "return." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Sarjis, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, traveled, he would seek refuge in Allah from the hardships of travel, the sorrow of returning, the regression after progress, and the supplication of the oppressed. And the evil of seeing his family and property. (Reported by Muslim) This is how it is in Sahih Muslim: Al-Hawr ba'da al-Kawni, with the letter "noon," and so did Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Nasa'i. Al-Tirmidhi said: It is narrated: Al-Kawru, with the letter "raa'," and both have validity. The scholars said: And its meaning with both "noon" and "raa'" is: returning from uprightness or increase to decrease. They said: The narration with "raa'" is taken from the coiling of a turban, which is its wrapping and gathering, and the narration with "noon" is from al-Kawnu, as a verbal noun, "kana yakunu kawnan" when it is found and established. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And Ali bin Rabiah said: I witnessed Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, brought a mount to ride. When he placed his foot in the stirrup, he said: "In the name of Allah." When he was settled on its back, he said: "Praise be to Allah, who made this subservient to us, and we were not able to do it, and to our Lord we shall return." Then he said: "Praise be to Allah," three times. Then he said: "Allah is the Greatest," three times. Then he said: "Glory be to You! I have wronged myself, so forgive me, for none can forgive sins but You." Then he laughed. It was said: "O Commander of the Faithful, what made you laugh?" He said: "I saw the Prophet, peace be upon him, do as I did, then he laughed. So I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, what made you laugh?' He said: 'Your Lord, Glorified be He, is amazed by His servant when he says: Forgive me my sins, knowing that none forgives sins but He.'" (Narrated by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi, who said: It is a hasan hadith. In some versions: a sahih hadith. This is the wording of Abu Dawud.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) reported: When we ascended, we used to say Takbir, and when we descended, we used to say Tasbih. (Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his armies ascended the high ground, they would say "Allahu Akbar" (God is Greatest), and when they descended, they would say "Subhan Allah" (Glory be to God). (Reported by Abu Dawud with a sound chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, when he returned from Hajj or Umrah, whenever he ascended a pass or a high sandy ground, he would say Takbir three times, then he would say: "There is no god but Allah, alone, without partner. To Him belongs all sovereignty and all praise. He is Powerful over all things. We are returning, repenting, worshipping, prostrating to our Lord, praising Him. Allah has fulfilled His promise, aided His servant, and defeated the confederates alone." (Agreed upon) And in a narration by Muslim: When he returned from armies or detachments or Hajj or Umrah. His saying: "awfa" means: ascended. And his saying: "fadafd" is with fatha on both fa's, with a silent daal between them and another daal at the end, and it is: a thick, elevated part of the earth. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that a man said: O Messenger of Allah, I want to travel, so give me advice. He said: "Adhere to the taqwa (fear/consciousness) of Allah, and say Takbir (Allah is the Greatest) on every high place." When the man turned away, he said: "O Allah, make the distance short for him, and make the journey easy for him." (Narrated by Tirmidhi and he said it is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, on a journey. When we ascended a valley, we used to say "La ilaha illa Allah" and "Allahu Akbar" and raise our voices. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O people, be gentle with yourselves, for you are not calling upon a deaf or absent one. He is with you, He is All-Hearing, Ever-Near." (Agreed upon) "Be gentle" with the "ba" unvowelled, meaning: be gentle with yourselves. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Three supplications are answered, without a doubt: the supplication of the oppressed, the supplication of the traveler, and the supplication of a parent against their child." (Reported by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan hadith). Abu Dawud's narration does not include "against their child". [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) that when the Messenger of Allah feared a people, he would say: "O Allah, we make You their shield, and we seek refuge in You from their evil." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Khawlah bint Hakim (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) say: "Whoever alights at a place and then says: 'I seek refuge in the perfect words of Allah from the evil of what He has created,' nothing will harm him until he departs from that place." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, traveled and night approached, he would say: "O Earth, my Lord and your Lord is Allah. I seek refuge in Allah from your evil, and the evil of what is in you, and the evil of what was created in you, and the evil of what walks upon you. I seek refuge in Allah from the evil of every lion and every black creature, and from the snake and the scorpion, and from the inhabitants of the land, and from the parent and what it begets." (Reported by Abu Dawud). And "al-aswad" means a person. Al-Khattabi said: "Saakin al-balad" (inhabitants of the land) refers to the jinn who are the dwellers of the earth. He said: And "al-balad" from the earth is what serves as a shelter for animals, even if there is no building or dwellings in it. He said: And it is possible that "al-walid" (the parent) refers to Iblis, and "ma walada" (what it begets) refers to the devils. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Travel is a piece of torment, preventing one of you from his food, drink, and sleep. When one of you has fulfilled his purpose of travel, he should hasten back to his family." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If one of you stays away for a long time, he should not approach his family at night." And in another narration, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade a man from approaching his family at night. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) used not to visit his family at night, and he would come to them in the morning or in the evening. (Agreed upon) Al-Turuq: coming at night. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that we were returning with the Prophet (peace be upon him), and when we reached the outskirts of Medina, he said: "Returning, repenting, worshipping, to our Lord praising." He kept repeating this until we entered Medina. (Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Ka'b bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) that when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) returned from a journey, he would begin with the Masjid and pray two rak'ahs in it. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "It is not permissible for a woman who believes in Allah and the Last Day to travel the distance of a day and a night except with a mahram." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, that he heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "No man should be alone with a woman except with a mahram, and no woman should travel except with a mahram." A man said to him: "O Messenger of Allah, my wife has gone out to perform Hajj, and I have enlisted for such and such a raid?" He said: "Go and perform Hajj with your wife." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Recite the Qur'an, for it will come on the Day of Resurrection as an intercessor for its companions." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Al-Nawwas bin Sam'an, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "On the Day of Resurrection, the Quran and its people, who used to act according to it in this world, will be brought forth. Surat Al-Baqarah and Al 'Imran will precede it, arguing on behalf of their owner." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Uthman ibn Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The best of you are those who learn the Quran and teach it." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The one who reads the Quran skillfully is with the noble, righteous scribes, and the one who reads the Quran and stumbles over it, and it is difficult for him, will have two rewards." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Musa al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The example of a believer who recites the Quran is like the citron: its scent is good and its taste is good. The example of a believer who does not recite the Quran is like a date: it has no scent, and its taste is sweet. The example of a hypocrite who recites the Quran is like the sweet basil: its scent is good and its taste is bitter. The example of a hypocrite who does not recite the Quran is like the colocynth: it has no scent and its taste is bitter." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah raises some people with this Book and lowers others with it." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no envy except in two cases: a man whom Allah has given the Quran, and he recites it day and night, and a man whom Allah has given wealth, and he spends it day and night." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Bara' ibn Azib (may Allah be pleased with them both) narrated: A man was reciting Surah Al-Kahf, and he had a horse tied with two ropes. A cloud covered him and began to descend, and his horse shied away from it. When morning came, he went to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and told him about it. He said: "That was the Sakinah (tranquility) that descended for the Quran." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever recites a letter from the Book of Allah has a good deed, and a good deed is tenfold. I do not say that Alif-Lam-Mim is one letter, but rather Alif is a letter, Lam is a letter, and Mim is a letter." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said: This is a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, he who has nothing of the Quran in his chest is like a ruined house." (Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said: It is a hasan sahih hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-As, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "It will be said to the companion of the Qur'an: 'Read and ascend, and chant as you used to chant in the world. For indeed, your station is at the last verse you recite.'" (Narrated by Abu Dawud and At-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, reported Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) as saying: "Keep in touch with the Quran, for by Him in Whose hand is the life of Muhammad, it is more prone to escape than a hobbled camel." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The likeness of the one who knows the Quran by heart is like the she-camel tied up. If he keeps hold of it, he retains it, and if he lets it go, it goes away." Muttafaqun `alayhi. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Allah has not listened to anything as much as He has listened to a Prophet with a beautiful voice reciting the Qur'an aloud." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: "You have been given a flute from the flutes of the family of David." (Agreed upon) And in a narration of Muslim: that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: "If you had seen me listening to your recitation yesterday." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Al-Bara' bin Azib (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: I heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) recite in the night prayer (Isha') from Surat At-Teen and Surat Az-Zaytun. I have never heard anyone with a more beautiful voice than his. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Lubabah Bashir bin Abdul Mundhir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "He who does not recite the Quran with a melodious voice is not of us." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a good chain of narration.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to me: "Recite the Qur'an to me." I said: "O Messenger of Allah, should I recite to you, when it was revealed to you?" He said: "I love to hear it from others." So I recited to him Surat An-Nisa until I reached this verse: "Then how [will it be] when We bring from every nation a witness and we bring you, [O Muhammad], against them as a witness?" He said: "That is enough for you now." So I turned to him, and his eyes were shedding tears. (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Sa'eed Raf' bin Al-Mu'alla (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to me: "Shall I not teach you the greatest Surah in the Qur'an before you leave the Masjid?" He took my hand, and when we were about to leave, I said: "O Messenger of Allah, you said you would teach me the greatest Surah in the Qur'an." He said: "Al-Hamdulillahi Rabbil-'alamin (Praise be to Allah, the Lord of the worlds) is the Seven Oft-Repeated Verses and the Great Qur'an which I have been given." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning: "Say, He is Allah, the One and Only": "By Him in Whose hand is my soul, it is equivalent to one-third of the Qur'an." And in another narration: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to his companions: "Is any one of you unable to recite one-third of the Qur'an in a night?" This was difficult for them, and they said: "Who among us can do that, O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "Say, He is Allah, the One and Only, is one-third of the Qur'an." (Reported by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, a man heard another man reciting: "{Say, He is Allah, [who is] One,}" repeating it. When morning came, he went to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and mentioned that to him. The man thought it was a small amount. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "By the One in whose hand is my soul, it is equivalent to one-third of the Quran." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said regarding: "Say, 'He is Allah, [who is] One'" [Quran 112:1] "It is equivalent to one-third of the Quran." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas, may God be pleased with him, that a man said: O Messenger of God, I love this surah, "Say, He is Allah, the One." He said: "Indeed, your love for it will admit you to Paradise." (Narrated by Tirmidhi and said: A hasan hadith - Narrated by Bukhari in his Sahih in a suspended manner). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from 'Uqbah ibn 'Amir (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Have you not seen verses that were revealed tonight, the like of which has never been seen? Say: 'I seek refuge in the Lord of the dawn,' and say: 'I seek refuge in the Lord of mankind.'" (Reported by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'eed Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to seek refuge from the jinn and the evil eye, until the two surahs (Al-Falaq and An-Nas) were revealed. When they were revealed, he took to them and abandoned what was other than them. (Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said: Hadith Hasan). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "There is a Surah in the Qur'an that has thirty verses, which intercedes for a man until he is forgiven, and it is: Blessed is He in Whose hand is the dominion." (Reported by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi, who said: "A hadith hasan," and in the narration of Abu Dawud: "intercedes"). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Mas'ud Al-Badri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "Whoever recites the last two verses of Surah Al-Baqarah at night, they will suffice him." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Do not make your houses graves. Verily, Satan is repelled from the house in which Surah Al-Baqarah is recited." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ubayy ibn Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O Aba Al-Mundhir, do you know which verse in the Book of Allah you have is the greatest?" I said: "Allah! There is no god but He, the Living, the Self-Subsisting." So he struck me in the chest and said: "Congratulations on your knowledge, Aba Al-Mundhir." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entrusted me with guarding the charity of Ramadan. Then a person came and began to scoop up the food. I seized him and said: I will take you to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He said: I am in need, I have dependents, and I am in great need. So I let him go. The next morning, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O Abu Hurairah, what did your captive do last night?" I said: O Messenger of Allah, he complained of need and having dependents, so I had mercy on him and let him go. He said: "As for him, he lied to you and will return." I knew that he would return because of the words of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so I lay in wait for him. He came and began to scoop up the food. I said: I will take you to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He said: Let me go, for I am in need and have dependents, I will not return. So I had mercy on him and let him go. The next morning, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to me: "O Abu Hurairah, what did your captive do last night?" I said: O Messenger of Allah, he complained of need and having dependents, so I had mercy on him and let him go. He said: "He lied to you and will return." So I lay in wait for him for the third time. He came and began to scoop up the food. I seized him and said: I will take you to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and this is the third time that you claim you will not return, and then you return! He said: Let me go, and I will teach you some words by which Allah will benefit you. I said: What are they? He said: When you go to your bed, recite the Verse of the Throne, for there will always be a guardian from Allah with you, and no devil will come near you until morning. So I let him go. The next morning, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to me: "What did your captive do last night?" I said: O Messenger of Allah, he claimed to teach me some words by which Allah will benefit me, so I let him go. He said: "What are they?" I said: He told me: When you go to your bed, recite the Verse of the Throne from its beginning until the end of the verse: {Allah! There is no god but He, the Living, the Self-subsisting}. And he told me: There will always be a guardian from Allah with you, and no devil will come near you until morning. Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "As for him, he spoke the truth to you, although he is a liar. Do you know who you were speaking to for three nights, O Abu Hurairah?" I said: No. He said: "That was Satan." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Ad-Darda' (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever memorizes ten verses from the beginning of Surah Al-Kahf will be protected from the Dajjal." And in another narration: "from the end of Surah Al-Kahf." (Both were narrated by Muslim.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: While Gabriel, peace be upon him, was sitting with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he heard a rattling from above him. So he raised his head and said: "This is a gate from the heaven that was opened today, and it has never been opened except today. So an angel descended from it and said: This is an angel who descended to Earth, and he has never descended except today. He greeted and said: Be glad with two lights that you have been given, which no prophet before you was given: The Opening of the Book, and the last verses of Surah Al-Baqarah. You will not recite a letter from them except that you will be given it." (Narrated by Muslim). Al-Naqeeth: The sound. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) said: "No group of people gathers in one of the houses of Allah, reciting the Book of Allah and studying it amongst themselves, but that tranquility descends upon them, and mercy covers them, and the angels surround them, and Allah mentions them to those who are with Him." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "My Ummah will be called on the Day of Resurrection with their foreheads and limbs shining white from the marks of ablution. So whoever among you can lengthen his blaze, let him do so." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: I heard my beloved, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "The adornment reaches from the believer as far as ablution reaches." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Uthman ibn Affan (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever performs Wudu' perfectly, his sins will come out from his body, even from beneath his fingernails." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, perform ablution like my ablution. Then he said: "Whoever performs ablution like this, his past sins will be forgiven, and his prayer and his walking to the mosque will be supererogatory." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When a Muslim slave - or a believer - performs Wudu' and washes his face, every sin that his eyes have looked at is washed away from his face with the water, or with the last drop of water. When he washes his hands, every sin that his hands have committed is washed away from his hands with the water, or with the last drop of water. When he washes his feet, every sin that his feet have walked towards is washed away from his feet with the water, or with the last drop of water, until he emerges pure from sins." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came to the graveyard and said: "Peace be upon you, O abode of believing people, and we, God willing, will join you. I wish we had seen our brothers." They said: "Are we not your brothers, O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "You are my companions, and our brothers are those who have not yet come." They said: "How will you recognize those from your Ummah who have not yet come, O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "Do you not think that if a man had horses with white foreheads and legs among horses that are completely black, would he not recognize his horses?" They said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Then they will come with white foreheads and legs from ablution, and I will be ahead of them at the Cistern." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Shall I not tell you of something by which Allah erases sins and raises ranks? They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: "Completing ablution even when it is disliked, hastening one's steps to the mosques, and waiting for prayer after prayer, for that is Ribat, for that is Ribat." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Purity is half of faith." (Narrated by Muslim). It has preceded at length in the chapter of patience. And in the chapter is the hadith of Amr bin Absah, may Allah be pleased with him, which preceded at the end of the chapter of hope, and it is a great hadith, containing many good deeds. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated on the authority of Umar ibn Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: "None of you performs ablution and completes it well – or he said: perfects his ablution – then says: I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and His Messenger, but that the eight gates of Paradise will be opened for him, and he may enter from whichever gate he wishes." (Narrated by Muslim). And At-Tirmidhi added: "O Allah, make me among those who turn to You in repentance and make me among those who purify themselves." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "If people knew what was in the call to prayer and the first row, and they could not find any way to get it except by drawing lots, they would draw lots for it. If they knew what was in arriving early for prayer, they would race to it. If they knew what was in the 'Isha' and Fajr prayers, they would come to them even if crawling." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Mu'awiyah, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "The muezzins will have the longest necks on the Day of Resurrection." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Abu Sa'sa'ah that Abu Sa'eed Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) said to him: "I see that you love sheep and the desert. When you are with your sheep or in your desert and the call to prayer is made, raise your voice in the call, for no jinn, nor human, nor anything hears the extent of the caller's voice, but it will bear witness for him on the Day of Resurrection." Abu Sa'eed said: "I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When the call to prayer is made, Satan flees, farting, so that he may not hear the Adhan. When the call is finished, he returns. When the Iqamah is proclaimed, he flees again. When the Iqamah is finished, he returns again, and whispers to a person, saying: 'Remember such and such, remember such and such' - referring to things that he had not recalled before. This continues until a person becomes unsure of how many Rak'ahs he has prayed." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-'As, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, say: "When you hear the Adhan, say what he says, then send blessings upon me, for whoever sends blessings upon me once, Allah will send blessings upon him ten times, then ask Allah for Al-Wasilah for me, for it is a station in Paradise which only befits one of Allah's servants, and I hope that I may be that one. So whoever asks Allah for Al-Wasilah for me, he will be granted my intercession." (Reported by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Saeed Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When you hear the call to prayer, say as the muezzin says." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever says when he hears the call to prayer: 'O Allah, Lord of this perfect call and the established prayer, bestow upon Muhammad intercession and excellence, and raise him to the praised station which You have promised him,' my intercession will be lawful for him on the Day of Resurrection." (Reported by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Sa'd bin Abi Waqas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "Whoever says when he hears the muezzin: 'I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, alone, without partner, and that Muhammad is His servant and His messenger. I am pleased with Allah as Lord, and with Islam as religion,' his sins will be forgiven." (Narrated by Tirmidhi and said it is a hasan hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas reported that the Messenger of God said: "Supplication between the Adhan and the Iqamah is not rejected." Narrated by Abu Dawud and Tirmidhi, who said: "A hasan hadith." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Do you see if there were a river at the door of one of you, and he washed himself in it every day five times, would any dirt remain on him?" They said: No dirt would remain on him. He said: "That is like the five prayers, Allah erases sins with them." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "The parable of the five daily prayers is like a deep river flowing at the door of one of you, in which he washes himself five times every day." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, that a man kissed a woman, then came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and informed him. So Allah, the Exalted, revealed: "Establish prayer at the two ends of the day and in the first watches of the night. Indeed, good deeds do away with evil deeds." The man said: "Is this for me?" He said: "It is for all of my Ummah, all of them." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The five daily prayers, and from one Friday prayer to the next, are expiations for whatever sins may have been committed between them, as long as major sins are not committed." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Uthman ibn Affan (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: I heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Any Muslim who performs an obligatory prayer and perfects his wudu, his khushu' (humility), and his ruku' (bowing) will have it expiate for his sins as long as he does not commit a major sin, and this applies to all time." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever prays the two cool (morning and afternoon) prayers will enter Paradise." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Zuhair Imarah bin Ru'aybah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "No one who prays before sunrise and before sunset will enter the Fire." (11) (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jundub bin Sufyan (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever prays the Fajr prayer, he is under the protection of Allah. So beware, O son of Adam, lest Allah demand of you anything from His protection." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Angels of the night and angels of the day succeed each other among you, and they gather at the Fajr prayer and the Asr prayer. Then those who spent the night among you ascend, and Allah asks them - and He knows best about them: 'How did you leave My servants?' They say: 'We left them while they were praying, and we came to them while they were praying.'" (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jarir bin Abdullah Al-Bajali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We were with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and he looked at the full moon one night and said: "You will see your Lord just as you see this moon, and there will be no crowding in seeing Him. So if you can, do not miss a prayer before sunrise and before sunset, then do so." (Agreed upon). (And in another narration: "He looked at the moon on the fourteenth night"). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Buraydah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "Whoever misses the 'Asr prayer has had his deeds annulled." (Reported by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurayrah that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever goes to the mosque in the morning or in the evening, Allah will prepare for him a lodging in Paradise every time he goes in the morning or in the evening." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever purifies himself in his house, then goes to one of the houses of Allah, to fulfill one of the obligations of Allah, his steps, one of them will expiate a sin, and the other will raise him in rank." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And Abu Ubaydullah bin Ka'b (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that there was a man from the Ansar, and I do not know of anyone further from the Masjid than him, and he never missed a prayer! It was said to him: "Why don't you buy a donkey to ride in the darkness and the heat?" He said: "It would not please me if my house was next to the Masjid. I want my walk to the Masjid to be written down for me, and my return when I return to my family." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Allah has gathered all of that for you." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the areas around the Mosque became vacant, and the Banu Salama intended to move closer to the Mosque. When this reached the Prophet (peace be upon him), he said to them: "I have been informed that you intend to move closer to the Mosque?" They replied: "Yes, Messenger of Allah, we have intended that." So he said: "Banu Salama, stay in your homes, your footsteps are recorded. Stay in your homes, your footsteps are recorded." They said: "We are not pleased that we have moved." (Reported by Muslim. Bukhari reported a similar meaning from the narration of Anas). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The people who will receive the greatest reward for prayer are those who have walked the furthest to it. So the furthest, and the one who waits for the prayer until he prays it with the Imam, is greater in reward than the one who prays it and then sleeps." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Buraydah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "Give glad tidings to those who walk to the mosques in darkness with complete light on the Day of Resurrection." (Reported by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Shall I not tell you of something by which Allah erases sins and raises degrees?" They said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Perfecting Wudu' even when it is difficult, walking much to the mosques, and waiting for the prayer after the prayer. That is Ar-Ribat, that is Ar-Ribat." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'eed Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "If you see a man frequenting the mosques, then bear witness to his faith, for Allah Almighty said: 'Only those believe in Allah and the Last Day who believe in Allah and the Last Day.'" (Verse. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "One of you is still in prayer as long as prayer keeps him from turning back to his family, nothing prevents him from turning back to his family except prayer." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The angels supplicate for one of you as long as he remains in the place where he prayed, as long as he does not break his ritual purity. They say: 'O Allah, forgive him. O Allah, have mercy on him.'" (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, delayed the 'Isha' prayer until midnight. Then he turned to us with his face after he prayed and said: "The people have prayed and slept, and you have remained in prayer since you have been waiting for it." (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The prayer in congregation is better than the prayer of one man by twenty-seven degrees." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "The prayer of a man in congregation is multiplied by twenty-five times over his prayer in his house and his market. This is because when he performs his ablution well, then goes out to the mosque, being prompted by nothing but the prayer, he does not take a step without it being elevated by one degree and one sin being forgiven. When he prays, the angels continue to invoke blessings upon him as long as he remains in his prayer place, provided he does not break his ablution, saying: 'O Allah, bless him; O Allah, have mercy upon him.' And he remains in prayer as long as he waits for the prayer." (Agreed upon. This is the wording of Bukhari.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him it is narrated that a blind man came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: "O Messenger of Allah, I have no one to lead me to the mosque." So he asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, for permission to pray in his house. He granted him permission. When he turned to leave, he called him back and said to him: "Do you hear the call to prayer?" He said: "Yes." He said: "Then respond." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah – and it was said: Amr ibn Qays, known as Ibn Umm Maktum, the muezzin, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: O Messenger of Allah, the city is abundant with vermin and wild animals. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "You hear 'Hayya ala as-Salah, Hayya ala al-Falah' (Come to prayer, Come to success), so come forth." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a good chain of narration.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "By Him in Whose hand is my soul, I have intended to order that firewood be gathered, then to order that the prayer be called, then to order a man to lead the people in prayer, and then I go to men and burn their houses over them." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: Whoever is pleased to meet Allah, the Most High, tomorrow as a Muslim, let him be diligent in these prayers where they are called. For Allah has ordained for your Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, the ways of guidance, and they are among the ways of guidance. If you were to pray in your homes as this one who stays behind prays in his home, you would abandon the Sunnah of your Prophet. And if you abandon the Sunnah of your Prophet, you would go astray. I have seen us, and no one stayed behind from it except a hypocrite whose hypocrisy was known. And a man would be brought, supported between two men, until he was made to stand in the row. (Narrated by Muslim. And in another narration by him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, taught us the ways of guidance, and among the ways of guidance is praying in the mosque where the call to prayer is made.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu ad-Darda' (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "There is no three people in a village or among the Bedouins where prayer is not established among them, except that Satan has taken control of them. So adhere to the congregation, for the wolf only eats from the sheep that strays away." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a hasan chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Uthman bin Affan (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: "Whoever prays Isha in congregation, it is as if he stood for half the night. And whoever prays Fajr in congregation, it is as if he stood for the whole night." (Reported by Muslim). And in the narration of Tirmidhi from Uthman bin Affan (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever witnesses Isha in congregation, he will have the reward of standing for half the night. And whoever witnesses Isha and Fajr in congregation, he will have the reward of standing for the whole night." (Tirmidhi said: This is a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "And if they knew what was in the darkness and the morning, they would come to them even if crawling." (Agreed upon). It has been previously mentioned in full. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him it is narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no prayer heavier upon the hypocrites than Fajr and Isha prayers, and if they knew what was in them, they would come to them even if crawling." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "Which deeds are best?" He said: "The prayer at its appointed time." I said: "Then which?" He said: "Kindness to parents." I said: "Then which?" He said: "Jihad in the cause of Allah." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Islam is built upon five: testifying that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establishing prayer, giving zakat, performing the pilgrimage to the House, and fasting Ramadan." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I have been commanded to fight people until they testify that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, and they establish prayer and pay zakat. If they do that, their blood and wealth are protected from me, except by the right of Islam, and their reckoning is with Allah." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) sent him to Yemen and said: "You are going to a people of the Book. Invite them to testify that there is no god but Allah and that I am the Messenger of Allah. If they obey this, then inform them that Allah has obligated them to perform five prayers every day and night. If they obey this, then inform them that Allah has obligated them to give charity which is to be taken from their rich and distributed among their poor. If they obey this, then beware of the best of their property, and fear the supplication of the oppressed, for there is no veil between it and Allah." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Verily, between a man and shirk and kufr is the abandoning of prayer." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Buraydah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "The covenant between us and them is prayer, so whoever abandons it has committed disbelief." (Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Shaqiq bin Abdullah, the Tabi'i, whose greatness is agreed upon, may Allah have mercy on him, he said: "The companions of Muhammad, peace be upon him, did not consider anything among the deeds, leaving it would be disbelief, except for prayer." (Narrated by Tirmidhi in the Book of Faith with a sound chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The first thing the servant will be held accountable for on the Day of Resurrection is his prayer. If it is sound, he will have succeeded and prospered. If it is unsound, he will have failed and lost. If anything is lacking from his obligatory prayer, the Lord, Mighty and Majestic, will say: 'Look and see if My servant has any voluntary prayers, and make up for what was lacking from his obligatory prayer with them.' Then the rest of his deeds will be reckoned in this manner." (Reported by Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Jabir bin Samurah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) came out to us and said: "Will you not form ranks like the ranks of the angels before their Lord?" We said: "O Messenger of Allah, how do the angels form ranks before their Lord?" He said: "They complete the first ranks and stand close together in the rows." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If people knew what was in the call to prayer and the first row, and that they could not get it except by lot, they would cast lots for it." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him it is narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The best rows for men are the first ones, and the worst are the last ones. The best rows for women are the last ones, and the worst are the first ones." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'eed Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saw a delay among his companions, so he said to them: "Advance and pray behind me, and let those behind you pray behind you. A people will continue to delay until Allah delays them." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to touch our shoulders during prayer and say: "Straighten your rows, and do not be uneven, lest your hearts become uneven. Let those among you who are mature and sensible come next to me, then those who are next to them, then those who are next to them." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Straighten your rows, for straightening the rows is part of the perfection of the prayer." (Agreed upon) And in the narration of Al-Bukhari: "For straightening the rows is part of establishing the prayer." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him it is narrated that he said: The prayer was established, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) turned his face towards us and said: "Straighten your rows and stand shoulder to shoulder, for I see you from behind my back." (Narrated by Bukhari with his wording, and Muslim with its meaning). And in a narration by Bukhari: "One of us would press his shoulder against his companion's shoulder and his foot against his foot." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated from Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: "Straighten your rows, or Allah will make your faces differ." (Agreed upon) And in a narration of Muslim: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to straighten our rows as if he were straightening arrows, until he saw that we had understood him. Then one day he went out and stood up, almost to say the Takbir, and saw a man whose chest protruded from the row. He said: "O servants of Allah, straighten your rows, or Allah will make your faces differ." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with them, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would inspect the rows from one side to another, wiping our chests and shoulders and saying: "Do not differ, lest your hearts differ." And he would say: "Indeed, Allah and His angels send blessings upon the first rows." (Narrated by Abu Dawood with a hasan chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Straighten your rows, align your shoulders, fill the gaps, be gentle with your brothers' hands, and leave no gaps for Satan. Whoever joins a row, Allah will join him, and whoever cuts off a row, Allah will cut him off." (Reported by Abu Dawud with a sound chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Straighten your rows, bring them close together, and align your shoulders. By Him in Whose Hand is my soul, I see the devil entering through the gaps in the rows, like small sheep." (Sahih Hadith, narrated by Abu Dawud with a chain of narration that meets the condition of Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Complete the front row, then the row next to it, and whatever shortage there is, let it be in the back row." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a Hasan chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah and His angels send blessings upon the right sides of the rows." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Al-Bara', may Allah be pleased with him, he said: "When we prayed behind the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, we loved to be on his right side, facing him. I heard him say: 'O my Lord, protect me from Your punishment on the Day You raise - or gather - Your servants.'" (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Straighten the rows and fill the gaps." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Umm al-Mu'minin, Umm Habibah Ramlah bint Abi Sufyan, may Allah be pleased with them, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) saying: "There is no Muslim servant who prays for Allah, the Most High, twelve rak'ahs voluntarily every day, other than the obligatory prayers, except that Allah will build him a house in Paradise," or: "except that a house will be built for him in Paradise." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, he said: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, two rak'ahs before Dhuhr and two rak'ahs after it, and two rak'ahs after Friday prayer, and two rak'ahs after Maghrib, and two rak'ahs after Isha. (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Mughaffal, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Between every two calls to prayer there is a prayer, between every two calls to prayer there is a prayer, between every two calls to prayer there is a prayer." And he said in the third time: "For whoever wills." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not leave four (rak'ahs) before Dhuhr, and two (rak'ahs) before Fajr. (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from her, she said: "The Prophet, peace be upon him, was not more diligent in observing any of the voluntary prayers than he was in observing the two rak'ahs of Fajr." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from her, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "Two rak'ahs of Fajr are better than this world and all that is in it." (Reported by Muslim). And in another narration of theirs: "are dearer to me than the entire world." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Abdullah Bilal bin Rabah, may Allah be pleased with him, the muezzin of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, to call him for the dawn prayer. 'Aishah detained Bilal with a matter she asked him about, until it became very light. So Bilal stood up and called the prayer, and continued his call. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not come out. When he came out, he prayed with the people. He informed him that 'Aishah had detained him with a matter she asked him about until it became very light, and that he was late in coming out. So he (meaning the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him) said: "I had prayed the two rak'ahs of Fajr." He said: "O Messenger of Allah, has it become very light?" He said: "Even if it had become lighter than it was, I would have prayed them and done them well and beautifully." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a hasan chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to pray two light rak'ahs between the Adhan and the Iqamah for the morning prayer. (Agreed upon) And in a narration of theirs: He used to pray the two rak'ahs of Fajr when he heard the Adhan and he would make them light, so I would say, "Did he recite Umm al-Qur'an in them?" And in a narration of Muslim: He used to pray the two rak'ahs of Fajr when he heard the Adhan and make them light. And in a narration: When the dawn broke. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Hafsah, may Allah be pleased with her, that when the muezzin called for the Fajr prayer and dawn broke, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would pray two light rak'ahs. (Agreed upon). And in a narration of Muslim: When dawn broke, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would not pray except two light rak'ahs. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) that he said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to pray at night in units of two, and he would perform Witr with one rak'ah at the end of the night, and he would pray two rak'ahs before the dawn prayer, and it was as if the Adhan was in his ears." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to recite in the two rak'ahs of Fajr: in the first of them, "Say, 'We believe in Allah and what was revealed to us'" [2:136], the verse in Al-Baqarah. And in the second of them: "We believe in Allah and bear witness that we are Muslims" [3:81]. And in another narration: in the second of them, which is in Al-'Imran: "Come to a word common between us and you" [3:64]. (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, recited in the two Rak'ahs of Fajr: "Say, 'O disbelievers.'" and "Say, 'He is Allah, [who is] One.'" (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: "I observed the Prophet, peace be upon him, for a month reciting in the two Rak'ahs before Fajr: 'Say, O disbelievers,' and: 'Say, He is Allah, [who is] One.' (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said: a Hasan hadith)." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed the two rak'ahs of Fajr, he would lie on his right side. (Reported by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from her, she said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, used to pray between finishing the 'Isha' prayer and the Fajr prayer eleven rak'ahs, giving the tasleem between every two rak'ahs, and praying one witr rak'ah. When the mu'adhin finished the call for Fajr prayer, and the Fajr became clear and the mu'adhin came, he would stand and pray two light rak'ahs, then lie down on his right side thus until the mu'adhin came to call for the iqamah. (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When one of you prays the two rak'ahs of Fajr, he should lie down on his right side." (Reported by Abu Dawud and At-Tirmidhi with authentic chains of narration. At-Tirmidhi said: This is a hasan sahih hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) that he said: "I prayed two rak'ahs before Dhuhr and two rak'ahs after Dhuhr with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, did not leave four [units of prayer] before Dhuhr. (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from her, she said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, used to pray four rak'ahs in my house before Dhuhr, then he would go out and lead the people in prayer, then he would come back and pray two rak'ahs. He used to lead the people in Maghrib prayer, then enter my house and pray two rak'ahs, and he would lead the people in Isha prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Umm Habibah, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever preserves four rak'ahs before Zuhr and four after it, Allah will forbid him from the Fire." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and At-Tirmidhi). He said it is a hasan sahih hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Al-Sa'ib, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to pray four (rak'ahs) after the sun had passed its zenith, before Dhuhr. He said, "It is an hour in which the gates of heaven are opened, and I love that my deeds should ascend during it." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and said: A hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may God be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, if he did not pray four rak'ahs before Dhuhr, he would pray them after. (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, who said: It is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, used to pray four rak'ahs in the middle of the afternoon (Asr), separating them with a Tasleem (greeting) to the close angels, and to the Muslims and believers who followed them. Narrated by Tirmidhi and he said it is a Hasan hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Narrated Ibn `Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "May Allah have mercy on him who prays four rak'ahs before `Asr." (Reported by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to pray two rak'ahs before Asr. (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a Sahih chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Mughaffal, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "Pray before Maghrib." He said in the third time: "For whoever wishes." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, reported that he saw the elder companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, hurrying to the pillars at sunset. (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: "We used to pray two rak'ahs after sunset, before Maghrib, during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. It was said: 'Did the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, pray them?' He said: 'He saw us praying them, and he neither commanded us nor forbade us.'" (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him it is narrated that he said: We were in Medina, and when the muezzin called for Maghrib prayer, people would rush to the pillars and pray two rak'ahs. So much so that a stranger entering the mosque would think that the prayer had already been offered because of the multitude of people praying them. (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "When any one of you prays the Friday prayer, he should pray four rak'ahs after it." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, used to not pray after Friday until he departed, then he would pray two rak'ahs in his house. (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Zayd ibn Thabit (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O people, pray in your houses, for the prayer of a man is in his house except for the obligatory prayer." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
