He said: "Shall I not teach you words that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, taught me, which if you had a debt like Mount Uhud, Allah would pay it for you? Say: 'O Allah, suffice me with what is lawful of You, and enrich me with Your grace, from all besides You.'" (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said: It is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Imran bin Husain, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, taught his father Husain two phrases with which he would supplicate: "O Allah, inspire me with guidance, and protect me from the evil of my soul." (Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said: A hasan hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu al-Fadl al-Abbas bin Abdul Muttalib, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I said, O Messenger of Allah: Teach me something to ask Allah the Almighty. He said: "Ask Allah for well-being." I stayed for a few days, then I came and said: O Messenger of Allah: Teach me something to ask Allah the Almighty. He said to me: "O Abbas, O uncle of the Messenger of Allah, ask Allah for well-being in this world and the Hereafter." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and said: This is a hasan sahih hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Shahr bin Hawshab, he said: I said to Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with her: O Mother of the Believers, what was the most frequent supplication of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when he was with you? She said: His most frequent supplication was: "O Turner of the hearts, keep my heart firm on Your religion." (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, who said: This is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu ad-Darda', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Among the supplications of David, peace be upon him, was: 'O Allah, I ask You for Your love, and the love of those who love You, and for the deeds which will bring me to Your love. O Allah, make Your love more beloved to me than myself, and than my family, and than cold water.' " Reported by Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Be diligent with O you of Majesty and Generosity." It was narrated by Tirmidhi, and by Nasa'i from the narration of Rabiah bin Al-A'mir, the companion. Al-Hakim said it is a hadith with a sound chain of narration. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, supplicated with many supplications, and we did not memorize anything from them. We said: "O Messenger of Allah, you supplicated with many supplications, and we did not memorize anything from them." So he said: "Shall I not guide you to what encompasses all of that? You say: 'O Allah, I ask You for the good that Your Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, asked You for, and I seek refuge in You from the evil that Your Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, sought refuge from. You are the One from Whom help is sought, and upon You is the conveyance, and there is no might nor power except with Allah.'" It was narrated by Tirmidhi and he said it is a hasan hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Among the supplications of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was: "O Allah, I ask of You the things that bring about Your mercy, and the resolve of Your forgiveness, and safety from every sin, and the gain from every righteousness, and success in attaining Paradise, and salvation from the Fire." (Narrated by Al-Hakim Abu Abdullah, who said: It is a hadith with a sound chain of narration according to the criteria of Muslim.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu ad-Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) that he heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "No Muslim servant supplicates for his brother behind his back, except that the angel says: 'And for you the like of it.'" (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) used to say: "The prayer of a Muslim for his brother in his absence is answered. An angel is appointed over his head. Whenever he prays for his brother with good, the angel appointed over him says: 'Amen, and may you have the like of it.'" (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Usamah ibn Zayd, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever has a favor done for him and says to the one who did it: 'May Allah reward you with good,' he has indeed praised him adequately." [Reported by Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Sahih Hadith.] [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not invoke evil against yourselves, and do not invoke evil against your children, and do not invoke evil against your property, lest you coincide with a time from Allah when He is asked for something and He grants it to you." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The closest a servant is to his Lord is when he is prostrating, so make much supplication." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "The prayer of one of you will be answered as long as he does not hasten, saying: 'I have prayed to my Lord, and He has not answered me.'" (Agreed upon) And in a narration of Muslim: "The prayer of the slave will continue to be answered as long as he does not call for something sinful or the severing of ties of kinship, as long as he does not hasten." It was said: "O Messenger of Allah, what is hastening?" He said: "He says: 'I have prayed, and I have prayed, but I do not see that He is answering me,' so he becomes disheartened and gives up praying." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: It was said to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Which supplication is heard most?" He said: "The latter part of the night and after the obligatory prayers." Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ubadah ibn as-Samit, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no Muslim on the earth who supplicates to Allah, the Most High, with a supplication, except that Allah grants him it, or averts from him an equal amount of evil. As long as he does not supplicate for something sinful, or for the severing of ties of kinship." So a man from the people said: "Then we will supplicate a lot." He said: "Allah is more abundant." Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said it is a hasan sahih hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say at times of distress: "There is no god but Allah, the Mighty, the Forbearing. There is no god but Allah, the Lord of the Mighty Throne. There is no god but Allah, the Lord of the heavens and the Lord of the earth and the Lord of the noble throne." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Abu Muhammad Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Bakr al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the people of Suffah were poor people, and that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, once said: "Whoever has food for two, let him go with a third, and whoever has food for four, let him go with a fifth or a sixth," or words to that effect. And Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, brought three, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, went with ten. Abu Bakr had dinner with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, then stayed until he prayed Isha, then returned. He came after a time of the night that Allah willed. His wife said to him: "What kept you from your guests?" He said: "Did you not feed them?" She said: "They refused until you came, and they were offered food." He said: "So I went and hid myself." He said: "O Ghunthar, he insulted and reviled him, and said: 'Eat, but not to your satisfaction. By Allah, I will never eat it.'" He said: "And by Allah, we would not take a bite without more growing from beneath it than before, until they were full, and it became more than it was before." Abu Bakr looked at it and said to his wife: "O sister of Bani Firās, what is this?" She said: "No, by the coolness of my eyes, it is now three times more than it was before!" Abu Bakr ate from it and said: "This was from Satan," meaning his oath. Then he ate a bite from it, then carried it to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and it remained with him. There was a covenant between us and a people, and the time expired, and we dispersed, twelve men, with each man were people, Allah knows how many with each man, and they all ate from it. In one narration: Abu Bakr swore not to eat it, and the woman swore not to eat it, and the guest - or guests - swore not to eat it, or to feed them until he ate it. So Abu Bakr said: "This is from Satan!" He called for the food, and he ate, and they ate, and they would not lift a bite except that more grew from beneath it than before. He said: "O sister of Bani Firās, what is this?" She said: "By the coolness of my eyes, it is now more than it was before we ate." They ate, and he sent it to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and it was mentioned that he ate from it. In one narration: Abu Bakr said to Abd al-Rahman: "Here are your guests, for I am going to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Finish feeding them before I come." Abd al-Rahman went and brought them what he had. He said: "Eat." They said: "Where is our host?" He said: "Eat." They said: "We will not eat until our host comes." He said: "Accept our hospitality from us, for if he comes and you have not eaten, you will incur his displeasure." They refused. He knew that he was angry with him. When he came, I moved away from him. He said: "What did you do?" They informed him. He said: "O Abd al-Rahman," and he was silent. Then he said: "O Abd al-Rahman," and he was silent. Then he said: "O Ghunthar, I swear to you, if you hear my voice, come!" So I came out and said: "Ask your guests." They said: "He speaks the truth, he brought it to us." He said: "You were waiting for me. By Allah, I will not eat it tonight." The others said: "By Allah, we will not eat it until you eat it." He said: "Woe to you! Why do you not accept our hospitality from us? Bring your food." He brought it, and he put his hand on it and said: "In the name of Allah. The first was from Satan." He ate, and they ate. (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There were among the nations before you people who were spoken to, and if there is anyone among my nation, then it is Umar." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari, and narrated by Muslim from the narration of Aisha. In their narrations, Ibn Wahb said: "Muhaddathun" means inspired.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir bin Samurah, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: The people of Kufa complained about Sa'd - meaning Ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him - to Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. So he dismissed him and appointed Ammar over them. They complained until they mentioned that he did not know how to pray. So he sent for him and said: "O Abu Ishaq, these people claim that you do not know how to pray." He said: "As for me, by Allah, I used to pray with them the prayer of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. I would not shorten the prayer, and I would lengthen the first two units of the 'Isha' prayer, and shorten the last two." He said: "That is what we expect of you, O Abu Ishaq." And he sent with him a man - or men - to Kufa to ask the people of Kufa about him. He did not enter a mosque except that he asked about him, and they spoke well of him. Until he entered a mosque of Banu Abs, and a man from them stood up, known as Usamah bin Qatadah, whose kunya was Abu Sa'dah. He said: "Since you are asking us, Sa'd used to not march with a detachment, nor divide equally, nor be just in judgment." Sa'd said: "By Allah, I will pray for three things: O Allah, if this servant of Yours is a liar, and he stood up for riya' and sum'ah, then prolong his life, prolong his poverty, and expose him to trials." And after that, if he was asked, he would say: "An old man, afflicted. The supplication of Sa'd has reached me." Abdul Malik bin Umayr, the narrator from Jabir bin Samurah, said: "And I saw him after that, his eyebrows had fallen over his eyes due to old age, and he used to expose himself to young women in the streets and wink at them." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Urwah bin Az-Zubayr that Sa'id bin Zayd bin 'Amr bin Nufayl, may Allah be pleased with him, was disputed by Arwa bint Aws before Marwan bin Al-Hakam, and she claimed that he had taken some of her land. Sa'id said: "Would I take anything from her land after what I heard from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him?" He said: "What did you hear from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him?" He said: "I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: 'Whoever unlawfully takes a span of land, it will be a collar around his neck for seventy lands.'" Marwan said to him: "I will not ask for proof after this." Sa'id said: "O Allah, if she is a liar, then blind her sight and kill her in her land." He said: "She did not die until her sight was taken, and while she was walking in her land, she fell into a pit and died." (Agreed upon). And in a narration from Muslim from Muhammad bin Zayd bin Abdullah bin 'Umar with its meaning, that he saw her blind, feeling her way along the wall, saying: "The prayer of Sa'id has afflicted me," and that she passed by a well in the house in which she disputed with him, and fell into it, which became her grave. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) narrated: When Uhud approached, my father called me at night and said: "I have only seen myself being killed among the first to be killed of the companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). I am leaving behind no one dearer to me than you, except the person of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). I have a debt, so pay it off, and treat your sisters kindly." In the morning, he was the first to be killed. I buried him with another man in his grave. Then, I did not feel at ease leaving him with another, so I dug him up after six months, and he was as he was the day I placed him, except for his ear. So, I made a separate grave for him. (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that two men from the companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, went out from the Prophet, peace be upon him, on a dark night, and with them were like two lamps before them. When they parted, each one had one until he reached his family. (Narrated by Bukhari) by various routes, and in some of them the two men were Usayd ibn Hudayr and Abbad ibn Bishr, may Allah be pleased with them. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, sent ten men as scouts, under the command of Asim bin Thabit Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him. They set out until they reached Al-Hada, between 'Usfan and Mecca. They were informed of a tribe of Hudhayl called Banu Lihyan, who mobilized about a hundred archers against them. They followed their tracks, and when Asim and his companions sensed them, they took refuge in a place, and the people surrounded them. They said: "Descend and surrender yourselves, and you will have our pledge and covenant that we will not kill any of you." Asim bin Thabit said: "O people, as for me, I will not descend under the covenant of a disbeliever. O Allah, inform Your Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, about us." So they shot them with arrows and killed Asim. Three men surrendered to them on the strength of the covenant and pledge, including Khubayb, Zayd bin Al-Dathinnah, and another man. When they had them at their mercy, they untied their bowstrings and tied them with them. The third man said: "This is the first betrayal. By Allah, I will not accompany you; I have an example in these (referring to the slain)." They dragged him and struggled with him, but he refused to accompany them, so they killed him. They took Khubayb and Zayd bin Al-Dathinnah with them until they sold them in Mecca after the Battle of Badr. The Banu Al-Harith bin 'Amir bin Nawfal bin 'Abd Manaf bought Khubayb, and it was Khubayb who had killed Al-Harith on the day of Badr. Khubayb remained a prisoner with them until they decided to kill him. He asked for a razor from some of Al-Harith's daughters to shave himself, and she lent it to him. While she was distracted, a child of hers crawled towards him. She found him sitting on her lap with the razor in his hand. She screamed in terror, which Khubayb recognized. He said: "Are you afraid that I will kill him? I would not do that." She said: "By Allah, I have never seen a better prisoner than Khubayb. By Allah, I found him one day eating a bunch of grapes in his hand, and he was bound with iron, and there was no fruit in Mecca." She used to say: "This is sustenance that Allah has provided for Khubayb." When they took him out of the sanctuary to kill him in the open, Khubayb said to them: "Let me pray two rak'ahs." So they left him. He prayed two rak'ahs and said: "By Allah, if it were not that you would think that I am afraid, I would have prayed more." "O Allah, count them in number, and kill them dispersedly, and leave none of them." And he said: "Then I do not care when I am killed as a Muslim**on whatever side I fall to Allah. This is for the sake of Allah, and if He wills, He will bless my torn limbs." Khubayb was the one who initiated for every Muslim killed patiently the prayer, and the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, informed his companions of their news on the day they were afflicted. Some people from Quraysh sent to Asim bin Thabit when they heard that he had been killed, asking for something from him to identify him, as he had killed one of their great men. So Allah sent a swarm of bees like a canopy to Asim, which protected him from their messengers, and they were unable to cut anything from him. (Narrated by Bukhari) His saying "Al-Hada" means a place, and "Al-Dhalla" means a cloud, and "Al-Dabar" means bees. His saying "kill them dispersedly" is with a kasra on the baa and a fatha on it. Whoever says it with a kasra, he says it is the plural of "bidda" with a kasra on the baa, which means a share. And the meaning is: kill them in divided portions, each one of them having a share. And whoever says it with a fatha, he says the meaning is: killed separately, one after another, from dispersal. And in this chapter, there are many authentic hadiths that have preceded in their places in this book, including the hadith of the boy who used to go to the monk and the sorcerer, and the hadith of Jurayj, and the hadith of the companions of the cave who were trapped by the rock, and the hadith of the man who heard a voice in the clouds saying: "Water the garden of so-and-so," and others. And the proofs in this chapter are many and well-known, and by Allah is success. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: I have never heard Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, say about something, "I think it is such and such," except that it turned out to be as he thought. (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him speak good or remain silent." (Agreed upon). And this is explicit that one should not speak unless the speech is good, which is what its benefit has become apparent, and when one doubts the appearance of benefit, then one should not speak. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I said, "O Messenger of Allah, which of the Muslims is best?" He said, "He from whose tongue and hand the Muslims are safe." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Sahl bin Sa'd that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever guarantees to me what is between his jaws and what is between his legs, I will guarantee him Paradise." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that he heard the Prophet, peace be upon him, say: "Indeed, a servant may utter a word without thinking about it, and he slips into the Hellfire further than the distance between the East and the West." (Agreed upon). And "yutabaiyyanu" means to think about it whether it is good or not. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "A servant may utter a word that is pleasing to Allah the Almighty, and he does not think much of it, but Allah will raise his ranks because of it. And a servant may utter a word that incurs the wrath of Allah the Almighty, and he does not think much of it, but it will plunge him into Hell." (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Abd al-Rahman Bilal bin al-Harith al-Muzani, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "A man may utter a word that pleases Allah the Almighty, which he did not think would reach where it reached. Allah will record His pleasure with him until the Day he meets Him. And a man may utter a word that incurs Allah's wrath, which he did not think would reach where it reached. Allah will record His wrath with him until the Day he meets Him." (Narrated by Malik in Al-Muwatta and Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Sahih hadith.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Sufyan bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: I said, "O Messenger of Allah, tell me something that I can hold fast to." He said: "Say: My Lord is Allah, then remain steadfast." I said: "O Messenger of Allah, what is the thing you fear most for me?" He took hold of his own tongue and said: "This." Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan ghareeb hadith. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Do not speak much without the remembrance of Allah, for much speaking without the remembrance of Allah Almighty hardens the heart! And the furthest people from Allah are the hard-hearted." Narrated by Tirmidhi. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever Allah saves from the evil of what is between his two jaws and the evil of what is between his two legs will enter Paradise." (Reported by Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from 'Uqbah ibn 'Amir (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: "I said, 'O Messenger of Allah, what is salvation?' He said: 'Restrain your tongue, let your house suffice for you, and weep over your sins.'" (Narrated by Tirmidhi and said to be Hasan). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'eed Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "When the son of Adam wakes up, all his limbs humble themselves before the tongue, saying: 'Fear Allah concerning us, for indeed we are with you. If you are upright, we are upright, and if you are crooked, we are crooked.'" (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi). The meaning of "humble themselves before the tongue" is that they submit and are obedient to it. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: I said, "O Messenger of Allah, tell me of a deed that will admit me to Paradise and take me far from Hellfire." He said, "You have asked about a great matter, and it is easy for him for whom Allah Almighty makes it easy. You should worship Allah, associating nothing with Him, establish the prayer, pay the zakat, fast Ramadan, and perform the pilgrimage to the House if you are able to. Then he said, 'Shall I not inform you of the gates of goodness? Fasting is a shield, charity extinguishes sin as water extinguishes fire, and a person's prayer in the latter part of the night.' Then he recited: 'Their sides forsake their beds...' until he reached: '...they do.' (Surah As-Sajdah, 16-17). Then he said, 'Shall I not inform you of the head of the matter, its pillar, and its highest point?' I said, 'Yes, O Messenger of Allah.' He said, 'The head of the matter is Islam, its pillar is prayer, and its highest point is jihad.' Then he said, 'Shall I not inform you of what seals all of that?' I said, 'Yes, O Messenger of Allah.' He then took hold of his tongue and said, 'Restrain this.' I said, 'O Messenger of Allah, will we be held accountable for what we speak?' He said, 'May your mother be bereaved of you! What else but the harvests of their tongues will cast people into Hellfire on their faces?'" (Narrated by Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Sahih hadith, and it has been explained previously in a chapter before this one). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Do you know what gheebah is?" They said: "Allah and His Messenger know best." He said: "Mentioning your brother with what he dislikes." It was said: "What if what I say about my brother is true?" He said: "If it is true of him, then you have backbited him, and if it is not true of him, then you have slandered him." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said in his sermon on the Day of Sacrifice in Mina during the Farewell Pilgrimage: "Indeed, your blood, your wealth, and your honor are sacred to one another as this day of yours, in this month of yours, in this city of yours. Have I conveyed the message?" (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: I said to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "Enough from Safiyyah is so-and-so." Some narrators meant she is short. He said: "You have said a word that if it were mixed with the water of the sea, it would spoil it!" She said: And I imitated a person for him, and he said: "I would not like to have imitated a person, even if I had so-and-so." (Reported by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Sahih Hadith). And the meaning of "it would spoil it" is that it would mix with it a mixing that changes its taste or smell due to its extreme foulness and ugliness. And this Hadith is one of the most eloquent deterrents from backbiting. Allah the Almighty said: {And he does not speak from [his own] inclination. It is not but a revelation revealed.} [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "When I ascended, I passed by a people who had fingernails of copper and were scratching their faces and chests. I said, 'Who are these, O Gabriel?' He said, 'These are those who ate the flesh of people and attacked their honor!'" (Reported by Abu Dawud). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The blood, honor, and property of a Muslim are sacred to a Muslim." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Ad-Darda' that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever defends the honor of his brother, Allah will defend his face from the Fire on the Day of Resurrection." (Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, who said it is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Utban bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, in his famous long hadith that preceded in the chapter on hope, he said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, stood to pray and said: "Where is Malik bin Ad-Dukhshum?" A man said: He is a hypocrite, he does not love Allah and His Messenger. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Do not say that. Do you not see that he has said: 'There is no god but Allah,' seeking the face of Allah by that! And indeed, Allah has forbidden the Fire to anyone who says: 'There is no god but Allah,' seeking the face of Allah by that." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ka'b ibn Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, in his long hadith about his repentance, which has been mentioned before in the chapter of repentance. He said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, while sitting with the people in Tabuk, said: "What has Ka'b ibn Malik done?" A man from the tribe of Salimah said: "O Messenger of Allah, his two cloaks and his admiration for his own self have kept him back." Mu'adh ibn Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "What a terrible thing you have said! By Allah, O Messenger of Allah, we know nothing but good about him." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, remained silent. (Agreed upon). "His two sides" refers to his sides, and it is an indication of his self-admiration. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, reported that a man asked permission to enter upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. He said: "Allow him to enter, for he is a bad brother of the clan." (Agreed upon). Al-Bukhari used this as evidence for the permissibility of backbiting those who are corrupt and those who are suspicious. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from her, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I do not think so-and-so and so-and-so know anything of our religion." (Narrated by Bukhari). Al-Layth bin Sa'd, one of the narrators of this hadith, said: These two men were hypocrites. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Fatimah bint Qais (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: Abu Al-Jahm and Mu'awiyah have both proposed to me. So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "As for Mu'awiyah, he is poor and has no wealth, and as for Abu Al-Jahm, he does not put the stick down from his shoulder." (Agreed upon). And in a narration of Muslim: "As for Abu Al-Jahm, he is a striker of women," which is an interpretation of the narration: "he does not put the stick down from his shoulder." And it was said that its meaning is: he travels a lot. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Zayd bin Arqam (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We went out with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) on a journey, and the people suffered hardship. Abdullah bin Ubayy said: "Do not spend on those who are with the Messenger of Allah until they disperse." And he said: "If we return to Medina, the honourable will expel the humiliated from it." So I went to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and informed him of this. So he sent for Abdullah bin Ubayy, and he swore with great earnestness that he had not done it. They said: "Zayd lied to the Messenger of Allah." So I was greatly distressed by what they said, until Allah, the Almighty, sent down my confirmation: "When the hypocrites come to you..." Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) called them to seek forgiveness for them, and they turned their heads. (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, narrated: Hind, the wife of Abu Sufyan, said to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "Abu Sufyan is a stingy man, and he does not give me enough for myself and my children except what I take from him without his knowledge." He said: "Take what is sufficient for you and your children in a reasonable way." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Hudhaifah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "A tale-bearer shall not enter Paradise." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by two graves and said: "They are being punished, and they are not being punished for a great sin! Yes, it is a great sin. As for one of them, he used to go about spreading slander, and as for the other, he did not shield himself from his urine." (Agreed upon, and this is the wording of one of the narrations of Al-Bukhari). The scholars said: The meaning of "and they are not being punished for a great sin" is that it was not a great sin in their opinion, and it was said that it was a great sin that they neglected. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Shall I not inform you of what is al-'iddah? It is backbiting, spreading gossip among people." (Narrated by Muslim). Al-'iddah: with an open 'ayn, a silenced dhal, and a ha, on the pattern of "al-wajh". And it was narrated: al-'iddah, with a kasrah on the 'ayn and an open dhal, on the pattern of "al-'iddah", and it means: lying and slander. And according to the first narration: al-'iddah is a masdar (verbal noun), it is said: 'addahahu 'iddah, meaning: he slandered him with 'iddah. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Let no one among my companions inform me of anything about anyone, for I would like to meet you with a pure heart." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and Tirmidhi) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "You will find people to be mines; the best of them in the Jahiliyyah are the best of them in Islam, when they gain understanding. And you will find the best of people in this matter to be the most hateful of it. And you will find the worst of people to be the one with two faces, who comes to these people with one face, and to those people with another face." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Muhammad bin Zayd, that some people said to his grandfather Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): "We enter upon our rulers and say things to them that are contrary to what we say when we leave them." He said: "We used to consider this hypocrisy during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, truthfulness leads to righteousness, and righteousness leads to Paradise. And a man may speak the truth until he is recorded with Allah as a truthful person. And indeed, falsehood leads to wickedness, and wickedness leads to the Fire. And a man may lie until he is recorded with Allah as a liar." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Four things, if they are in a person, he is a pure hypocrite. And if any of them is in a person, he has a trait of hypocrisy until he abandons it: if he is entrusted, he betrays; if he speaks, he lies; if he makes a covenant, he breaks it; and if he quarrels, he acts immorally." (Agreed upon). Its explanation has preceded with the hadith of Abu Hurairah in a similar manner in the chapter on fulfilling covenants. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may God be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, may God’s blessings and peace be upon him, he said: "Whoever dreams of a dream he did not see will be tasked with tying two hairs together, and he will not be able to. And whoever listens to a people’s conversation while they dislike it, molten lead will be poured into his ears on the Day of Resurrection. And whoever makes an image will be tormented and tasked with breathing life into it, and he will not be able to." Narrated by Bukhari. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "The worst of lies is for a man to claim he saw with his eyes what they did not see." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari) And its meaning is: he says: "I saw something which I did not see." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

On the authority of Samura ibn Jundab (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) often used to say to his companions: "Did any of you see a dream?" and whoever Allah willed would narrate his dream. One morning he said to us: "Two came to me last night, and they said to me: 'Go forth.' So I went forth with them. We came upon a man lying down, and another standing over him with a rock. He was striking the man's head with the rock, smashing it, and the rock would roll away. He would follow the rock to pick it up, and it would not be whole until his head was restored as it was. Then he would return to him and do the same as he did the first time!" He said: "I said to them: 'Glory be to Allah! Who are these two?' They said to me: 'Go forth, go forth.' So we went forth, and we came upon a man lying on his back, and another standing over him with an iron hook. He would come to one side of his face and rip it open from cheek to nape, and his nostril to nape, and his eye to nape. Then he would move to the other side and do the same to that side as he did to the first side. As soon as he finished with that side, it would be restored as it was. Then he would return to him and do the same as he did the first time." He said: "I said: 'Glory be to Allah! Who are these two?' They said to me: 'Go forth, go forth.' So we went forth, and we came upon something like a furnace." I think he said: "And in it was a noise and voices. We looked into it and found naked men and women. Flames were coming up from beneath them, and when the flames reached them, they cried out." I said: "Who are these?" They said to me: "Go forth, go forth." So we went forth, and we came upon a river." I think he said: "It was red like blood. And in the river, a man was swimming. And on the bank of the river, a man had gathered many stones. And the swimmer would swim and swim, then come to the one who had gathered stones, who would open his mouth, and throw a stone into it. Then he would swim away. Then he would return to him. Every time he returned to him, his mouth would be opened, and a stone would be thrown into it." I said to them: "Who are these two?" They said to me: "Go forth, go forth." So we went forth, and we came upon a man with a repulsive appearance, or rather, the most repulsive man you could see. He had a fire with him that he was fanning and running around. I said to them: "What is this?" He said to me: "Go forth, go forth." So we went forth, and we came upon a lush, green meadow with all the colors of spring. And in the middle of the meadow was a very tall man, so tall that I could hardly see his head in the sky. And around the man were more young boys than I had ever seen. I said: "What is this! And who are these?" They said to me: "Go forth, go forth." So we went forth, and we came to a huge tree, larger and more beautiful than any tree I had ever seen! They said to me: "Climb it." So I climbed it, and we reached a city built of bricks of gold and bricks of silver. We came to the gate of the city and asked for it to be opened. It was opened for us, and we entered. We were met by men, half of whose creation was as beautiful as you could see, and half of whose creation was as ugly as you could see! They said to them: "Go and fall into that river," and it was a river flowing across, its water as pure white as milk. They went and fell into it. Then they returned to us, and the ugliness had gone from them, and they were in the most beautiful form. He said: They said to me: "This is the Garden of Eden, and that is your dwelling." My gaze rose, and I saw a palace like a white cloud. They said to me: "Is that your dwelling?" I said to them: "May Allah bless you. Let me enter." They said: "Not now, but you will enter it." I said to them: "I saw something wonderful last night. What is this that I saw?" They said to me: "We will tell you. As for the first man whose head you saw being smashed with a rock, he is the man who learns the Quran and abandons it, and sleeps through the obligatory prayer. As for the man whose face you saw ripped open from cheek to nape, and his nostril to nape, and his eye to nape, he is the man who goes out of his house and tells a lie that reaches the horizons, and he will be done to until the Day of Resurrection. As for the naked men and women who were in the furnace-like structure, they are the adulterers and adulteresses. As for the man you saw swimming in the river and being fed stones, he is the devourer of usury. As for the repulsive man by the fire, fanning it and running around it, he is Malik, the keeper of Hell. As for the tall man in the meadow, he is Ibrahim. As for the young boys around him, they are every child who died on the fitrah." And in a narration of Al-Barqani: "was born on the fitrah." Some Muslims said: "O Messenger of Allah, and the children of the polytheists?" The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "And the children of the polytheists." As for the people who were half beautiful and half ugly, they are a people who mixed good deeds with bad deeds. May Allah forgive them." (Narrated by Bukhari). And in another narration: "Last night I saw two men who came to me and took me out to a holy land." Then he mentioned: "So we went to a passage like a furnace, narrow at the top and wide at the bottom, with fire burning beneath it. When the fire rose, they would rise until they were almost out, and when it subsided, they would return to it, and there were naked men and women in it." And in it: "Until we came to a river of blood." And he did not doubt: "And a man was standing in the middle of the river, and on the bank of the river was a man with stones in front of him. The man in the river would come, and when he wanted to get out, the man would throw a stone into his mouth, and it would return him to where he was. Every time he came to get out, he would be thrown a stone in his mouth, and he would return as he was." And in it: "So they took me up the tree and brought me into a house more beautiful than any I had ever seen, with old men and young men in it." And in it: "The one you saw ripping his cheek is a liar, who tells a lie that is carried by others until it reaches the horizons, and he will be done to as you saw until the Day of Resurrection." And in it: "The one you saw having his head smashed is a man whom Allah taught the Quran, and he slept through it at night and did not act upon it during the day, so he will be done to until the Day of Resurrection. And the first house you entered is the house of the common believers, and as for this house, it is the house of the martyrs. And I am Gabriel, and this is Michael. So lift your head." I lifted my head, and above me was something like clouds. They said: "That is your dwelling." I said: "Let me enter my dwelling." They said: "You have a remaining lifespan that you have not completed. If you had completed it, you would have reached your dwelling." (Narrated by Bukhari). His saying: "يثلغ رأسه" (yathlghu ra'sah) is with the letter tha (ث) and ghayn (غ), meaning: it smashes and splits his head. His saying: "يتدهده" (yatadahdah) means: it rolls. And "الكلوب" (al-kuloob) with the opening kaf and doubled lam, is known. His saying: "فيشرشر" (fayusharshiru) means: he cuts. His saying: "ضوضوا" (dawdawu) is with two mu'jam letters dad (ض), meaning: they cried out. His saying: "فيفغر" (fayafgharu) is with fa (ف) and ghayn (غ), meaning: he opens. His saying: "المرآة" (al-mir'aat) is with an open mim (م), meaning: the appearance. His saying: "يحشها" (yahushshuha) is with an open ya (ي) and a dammah on ha (ح) and mu'jam shin (ش), meaning: he fuels it. His saying: "روضة معتمة" (rawdatun mu'tamah) is with a dammah on mim (م) and sukkoon on 'ayn (ع) and an open ta (ت) and a shaddah on mim (م), meaning: abundant in vegetation and tall. His saying: "دوحة" (dawhah) is with an open daal (د) and sukkoon on waw (و) and a mu'jam ha (ح), meaning: a large tree. His saying: "المحض" (al-mahd) is with an open mim (م) and sukkoon on ha (ح) and mu'jam dad (ض), meaning: milk. His saying: "فسما بصري" (fasama basari) means: my sight rose. And "صعدا" (sa'adan) is with a dammah on sad (ص) and 'ayn (ع), meaning: elevated. And "الربابة" (ar-rababah) is with an open ra (ر) and a mu'jam ba (ب) repeated, meaning: a cloud. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated on the authority of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "It is enough of a lie for a man to narrate everything he hears." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Samura (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever narrates a Hadith from me and he thinks it is a lie, then he is one of the liars." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Asma (may Allah be pleased with her) that a woman said: "O Messenger of Allah, I have a co-wife, is there any sin upon me if I pretend to be satisfied by my husband, other than what he gives me?" The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "He who pretends to be satisfied with what he has not received is like one who wears two garments of deceit." (Agreed upon). "Al-mutashabbi'" means one who appears full but is not, and its meaning here is that he appears to have achieved a virtue that he has not actually achieved. And "wearer of two garments of deceit" means one who deceives people by presenting himself as an ascetic, a scholar, or wealthy in order to be deceived by people, when he is not of that quality, and other meanings have been stated. And Allah knows best. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Shall I not inform you of the greatest of sins?" We said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Associating partners with Allah, and disobedience to parents." He was reclining and then sat up, and said: "And the false speech!" And he kept repeating it until we said: "We wish he would stop." Agreed upon. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Zayd Thabit bin Ad-Dahhak Al-Ansari (may Allah be pleased with him), who was from the people of the Pledge of Satisfaction, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever swears an oath by a religion other than Islam falsely and intentionally, then he is as he said. And whoever kills himself with something, he will be tormented with it on the Day of Resurrection. And a man does not have to fulfill a vow concerning what he does not own. And cursing a believer is like killing him." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "It is not fitting for a believer to be a great curser." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Ad-Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Those who curse will not be intercessors, nor witnesses on the Day of Resurrection." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Samurah bin Jundub (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Do not curse with the curse of Allah, nor with His wrath, nor with the Fire." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The believer is not a slanderer, nor a curser, nor an obscene, nor a foul-mouthed one." (Reported by Al-Tirmidhi and he said it is a hasan hadith). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu ad-Darda', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When a servant curses something, the curse ascends to the heaven, and the gates of heaven are shut against it. Then it descends to the earth, and its gates are shut against it. Then it goes to the right and to the left, and if it finds no way out, it returns to the one who was cursed. If he deserved it, well and good. Otherwise, it returns to the one who uttered it." Reported by Abu Dawud. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Imran ibn Husain, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: While the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was on one of his journeys, there was a woman from the Ansar on a camel, and she became annoyed and cursed it. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, heard that and said: "Take what is on her and leave her, for she is cursed." Imran said: "It is as if I see her now walking among people, and no one bothers her." (Reported by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Barzah Nadhla bin Ubaid Al-Aslami, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: While a young woman was on a she-camel carrying some of the people's belongings, she saw the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. The mountain path became narrow for them, so she said: "Hal! O Allah, curse it." The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A she-camel upon which there is a curse shall not accompany us." (Narrated by Muslim). His saying: "Hal" with a Fatha on the Ha and Sukun on the Lam, is a word used to scold camels. Know that the meaning of this Hadith may seem problematic, but there is no problem with it. Rather, the intention is to forbid that she-camel from accompanying them, and there is no prohibition against selling it, slaughtering it, or riding it when not in the company of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Rather, all of that and other dispositions are permissible and not forbidden, except for its accompanying him, peace and blessings be upon him. This is because all these actions were permissible, so some of them were forbidden, leaving the rest as it was. And Allah knows best. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Cursing a Muslim is wickedness, and fighting him is disbelief." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "No man accuses another man of immorality or disbelief, unless it returns upon him if his companion is not as he accused him." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "When two people exchange insults, the one who started it bears the sin, unless the wronged one transgresses." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him it is narrated that he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was brought a man who had drunk. He said: "Strike him." Abu Hurayrah said: Some of us struck him with our hands, some with our sandals, and some with our clothes. When he left, some of the people said: "May Allah disgrace you." He said: "Do not say this; do not aid Satan against him." (Narrated by Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Whoever accuses his slave of adultery, the prescribed punishment will be inflicted upon him on the Day of Resurrection, unless he is as he said." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not curse the dead, for they have reached what they have sent forth." (Narrated by Al-Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-'As, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "A Muslim is one from whose tongue and hand Muslims are safe, and a Muhajir is one who abandons what Allah has forbidden." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, it is narrated, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever wishes to be spared from the Hellfire and enter Paradise, then let his death come to him while he believes in Allah and the Last Day, and let him treat people as he wishes to be treated." (Narrated by Muslim). This is part of a long hadith previously mentioned in the chapter on obedience to those in authority. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Do not hate each other, do not envy each other, do not turn your backs on each other, do not shun each other, and be, O slaves of Allah, brothers. It is not permissible for a Muslim to shun his brother for more than three nights." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The gates of Paradise are opened on Monday and Thursday, and every servant who does not associate anything with Allah is forgiven, except for a man between whom and his brother there is enmity. It is said: 'Wait for these two until they reconcile! Wait for these two until they reconcile!'" (Reported by Muslim). And in another narration by him: "Deeds are presented every Thursday and Monday." and he mentioned something similar. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Beware of envy, for envy consumes good deeds just as fire consumes firewood, or he said, grass." Reported by Abu Dawud. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Beware of suspicion, for suspicion is the most lying of speech. Do not spy on one another, do not seek out each other's faults, do not compete with one another, do not envy one another, do not hate one another, do not turn your backs on one another, and be O servants of Allah, brothers as He commanded you. A Muslim is the brother of a Muslim; he does not wrong him, nor does he forsake him, nor does he look down upon him. Piety is here," and he pointed to his chest, "It is enough evil for a man to look down upon his Muslim brother. The whole of a Muslim is inviolable to another Muslim: his blood, his honor, and his property. Allah does not look at your bodies, nor at your faces, but He looks at your hearts and your deeds." In another narration: "Do not envy one another, do not hate one another, do not spy on one another, do not seek out each other's faults, do not outbid one another, and be O servants of Allah, brothers." In another narration: "Do not cut off relations with one another, do not turn your backs on one another, do not hate one another, do not envy one another, and be O servants of Allah, brothers." In another narration: "Do not boycott one another, and do not bid over the bid of one another." (Narrated by Muslim with all these narrations, and Bukhari narrated most of them.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Mu'awiyah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Verily, if you follow the private affairs of the Muslims, you will corrupt them, or you will almost corrupt them." This is a sound hadith, narrated by Abu Dawud with a sound chain of narration. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, that a man was brought to him and it was said to him, "This is so-and-so, his beard is dripping with wine." He said, "We have been forbidden from spying, but if something becomes apparent to us, we will act upon it." A hasan sahih hadith, narrated by Abu Dawud with a chain according to the condition of Bukhari and Muslim. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Beware of suspicion, for suspicion is the falsest of speech." (Agreed upon). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "It is enough evil for a man to look down upon a Muslim." (Narrated by Muslim, and it was previously narrated in full.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "No one will enter Paradise who has an atom's weight of pride in his heart." A man said: "A man likes his clothes to be nice, and his shoes to be nice." He said: "Allah is beautiful and loves beauty. Pride is rejecting the truth and looking down on people." (Narrated by Muslim). And the meaning of "rejecting the truth" is to deny it, and "looking down on them" is to belittle them. This has been explained more clearly than this before in the chapter on pride. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And on the authority of Jundub bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "A man said: By Allah, Allah will not forgive so-and-so. Then Allah, the Almighty, said: Who is it that swears by Me not to forgive so-and-so! Indeed, I have forgiven him, and I have nullified your deeds." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Wathilah ibn al-Asqa', may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not show malice towards your brother, lest Allah have mercy on him and test you." (Reported by Al-Tirmidhi and said: It is a Hasan Hadith). In this regard, the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, previously mentioned in the chapter on espionage: "The blood of a Muslim is forbidden to a Muslim," and so on. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There are two characteristics among people that are acts of disbelief: disparaging the lineage of others and wailing over the dead." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "He who carries arms against us is not of us, and he who deceives us is not of us." (Narrated by Muslim). And in another narration, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed by a pile of food and put his hand into it, and his fingers felt dampness. He said: "What is this, O owner of the food?" He said: "It was rained on, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Why did you not place it on top of the food so that people could see it! He who deceives us is not of us." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
And from him, the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "Do not bid against each other artificially." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]
And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) forbade Najsh (auction trickery). (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: A man mentioned to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, that he was deceived in sales. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Who did you buy from? Say: No deceit." (Agreed upon). "Al-khilabah" is with a khā' with a dot, and a bā' with a dot. It means deception. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever corrupts a man's wife or his servant is not one of us." "Khababa" with a marked khā', then a repeated unified bā': meaning, he corrupted him and deceived him. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-As (may Allah be pleased with them both) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Four qualities, if found in a person, make him a pure hypocrite. If any of these qualities are found in him, then he has a quality of hypocrisy until he abandons it: when he is entrusted with something, he betrays that trust; when he speaks, he lies; when he makes a covenant, he breaks it; and when he disputes, he is wicked." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, Ibn 'Umar, and Anas, may Allah be pleased with them, they said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Every traitor will have a banner on the Day of Resurrection, and it will be proclaimed: 'This is the treachery of so-and-so.'" (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Every traitor will have a banner raised for him on the Day of Resurrection by his backside, according to the extent of his betrayal. Verily, no traitor is more treacherous than a ruler of the general public." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: Allah the Almighty said: "Three I will be an opponent of on the Day of Resurrection: a man who gives Me a promise and then breaks it, a man who sells a free man and eats his price, and a man who hires a worker and takes full service from him, but does not give him his wages." (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "There are three whom Allah will not speak to on the Day of Resurrection, nor look at them, nor purify them, and for them is a painful punishment." He said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, recited this three times. Abu Dharr said: They are ruined and have lost, who are they, O Messenger of Allah? He said: The one who lets his garment trail, the one who boasts of his gifts, and the one who sells his goods by taking a false oath." (Narrated by Muslim). And in another narration by him: "The one who lets his garment trail," meaning: the one who lets his garment and clothes trail below the ankles out of pride. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Iyad bin Himar, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah the Almighty revealed to me that you should be humble, so that no one transgresses against another, and no one boasts over another." (Narrated by Muslim) The linguists said: Al-baghy is transgression and arrogance. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "If a man says, 'The people are ruined,' then he is the one who has ruined them." (Narrated by Muslim). The famous narration is "ahlakakum" with a dammah on the kaf, and it was narrated with a fatha. This is the forbidden (haram). As for he who says it out of pride in himself, looking down on people, and elevating himself above them, this is the forbidden. As for he who says it when he sees deficiency in people regarding their religion, and says it out of sadness for them and for the religion, then there is no harm in it. This is how the scholars interpreted and detailed it, and it was said by prominent Imams such as Malik bin Anas, Al-Khattabi, Al-Humaydi, and others. I have clarified this in the book "Al-Adhkar." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Do not cut off from one another, do not turn your backs on one another, do not hate one another, and do not envy one another. Be, O servants of Allah, brothers to one another. It is not lawful for a Muslim to forsake his brother for more than three nights." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is not permissible for a Muslim to forsake his brother for more than three nights, as they meet and turn away from each other. The best of the two is the one who initiates the greeting of peace. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Deeds are presented on every Monday and Thursday, and Allah forgives every person who does not associate anything with Allah, except for a person who has enmity between him and his brother. Then it is said: 'Leave these two until they reconcile.'" (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: "Indeed, Satan has despaired of being worshipped by the worshippers in the Arabian Peninsula, but [he hopes] in sowing discord among them." (Narrated by Muslim). Al-Tahreesh: is causing corruption, changing their hearts, and making them estranged from each other. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "It is not permissible for a Muslim to forsake his brother for more than three nights. Whoever forsakes his brother for more than three nights and dies, he enters Hellfire." (Narrated by Abu Dawud with a chain of narration according to the conditions of Bukhari). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Kharash, Hardad bin Abi Hardad Al-Aslami, and it is said Al-Sulami, the companion, may Allah be pleased with him, that he heard the Prophet, peace be upon him, say: "Whoever estranges himself from his brother for a year is like spilling his blood." (Reported by Abu Dawud with a sound chain of narration). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It is narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "It is not permissible for a Muslim to forsake another Muslim for more than three days. If three days have passed, he should meet him and greet him with peace. If he replies to the greeting, then they both share in the reward. If he does not reply, then he has incurred sin, and the Muslim has exited the state of forsaking." (Narrated by Abu Dawood with a Hasan chain of narration. Abu Dawood said: If the forsaking is for the sake of Allah, then it is not included in this.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) that the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) said: "If you are three, then two should not whisper to each other without the third." (Agreed upon). (Reported by Abu Dawud and added: Abu Salih said: I asked Ibn Umar, "What about four?" He said: It does not harm you). (Reported by Malik in Al-Muwatta: from Abdullah bin Dinar, he said: I and Ibn Umar were at the house of Khalid bin Uqbah which is in the market. A man came wanting to whisper to him, and there was no one with Ibn Umar except me. So Ibn Umar called another man until we were four. Then he said to me and to the third man he called: "Step back a little, for I heard the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) say: 'Two should not whisper to each other without one.'") [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When you are three, then two shall not whisper to each other, excluding the third, until you mingle with the people, for indeed that grieves him." (Agreed upon) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) that the Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) said: "A woman was punished because of a cat which she had tied up, and it died of hunger. Because of this, she entered the Fire. She did not feed it nor give it water, nor did she let it eat of the vermin of the earth." (Agreed upon). "Vermin of the earth" is pronounced with the vowel point on the Kha' and the repeated Shin, and it means its insects and small creatures. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, that he passed by some youths of Quraish who had set up a bird and were shooting at it, and they had made for the owner of the bird every stray arrow of theirs. When they saw Ibn Umar, they dispersed. Ibn Umar said: "Who did this? May Allah curse whoever did this, for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) cursed whoever takes anything with a soul as a target." (Agreed upon). "Al-Gharadh": with the opening of the Ghayn and the Ra', and it is the target, and the thing that is aimed at. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade the torturing of animals. (Agreed upon). And its meaning is: to be kept for slaughter. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Ali Suwaid bin Muqarrin, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: "I saw myself as the seventh of seven brothers from the sons of Muqarrin, and we had no servant except one. The youngest of us slapped her, so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded us to set her free." (Narrated by Muslim). And in another narration: "The seventh of my brothers." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Mas'ud Al-Badri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "I was beating my slave with a whip. I heard a voice behind me, saying: 'Know, O Abu Mas'ud!' I did not understand the voice due to my anger. When he came closer to me, it was the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). He said: 'Know, O Abu Mas'ud, that Allah has power over you, greater than your power over this slave.' I said: 'I will never beat a slave again after this.'" (In one narration: "The whip fell from my hand out of his reverence.") (In another narration: "I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, he is free for the sake of Allah the Almighty.' He said: 'Had you not done so, the Fire would have scorched you, or touched you.'") (Narrated by Muslim with these narrations). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever strikes his slave a punishment he has not earned, or slaps him, then his expiation is to set him free." (Narrated by Muslim) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Hisham bin Hakim bin Hizam, may Allah be pleased with him, that he passed by Al-Sham and saw some Nabataeans, who were made to stand in the sun, and oil was poured on their heads. He said: "What is this?" They are being tortured for the land tax. In another narration: They were imprisoned for the poll tax. Hisham said: "I bear witness that I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: 'Indeed, Allah punishes those who punish people in this world.'" So he went to the ruler and told him, and he ordered them to be released." (Narrated by Muslim. "Al-Nabata" means the farmers from the non-Arabs.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saw a donkey branded on its face, and he disliked that. He said: "By Allah, I will not brand it except on the furthest part of the face." And he ordered his donkey to be branded on its hindquarters, and he was the first to brand the hindquarters. (Narrated by Muslim). "The hindquarters" means the sides of the hips around the anus. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by a donkey that had been branded on its face, and he said: "May Allah curse the one who branded it." (Narrated by Muslim. And in another narration by Muslim as well: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade striking the face and branding the face.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: The Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) sent us on an expedition and said: "If you find so-and-so and so-and-so," naming two men from Quraish, "then burn them with fire." Then the Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) said when we were about to set out: "I had ordered you to burn so-and-so and so-and-so, and indeed none punishes with fire except Allah. So if you find them, then kill them." (Narrated by Bukhari) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on a journey. He went to relieve himself, and we saw a bird with two chicks. We took its chicks. The bird came and began to flutter. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, came and said: "Who has distressed this bird by taking its young? Return its young to it." He saw an anthill that we had burned, and he said: "Who burned this?" We said: "We did." He said: "Indeed, none should torment with fire except the Lord of fire." His statement, "an anthill," means: the place of the ants with the ants. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Procrastinating by one who is well-off is oppression, and if one of you is made bankrupt for a solvent person, then he should accept." (Agreed upon. The meaning of "bankrupt" is: referred.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

It was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The one who takes back his gift is like a dog that vomits and then returns to its vomit." (Agreed upon). In one narration: "The one who takes back his charity is like a dog that vomits, then returns to its vomit and eats it." And in another narration: "The one who takes back his gift is like the one who returns to his vomit." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Umar ibn Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: "I once equipped a horse for jihad. The one who was entrusted with it lost it. I wanted to buy it back, thinking that he would sell it cheaply. So I asked the Prophet, peace be upon him, and he said: 'Do not buy it back, and do not take back your charity, even if he gives it to you for one dirham. For the one who takes back his charity is like the one who takes back his vomit.'" (Agreed upon). His saying: "I once equipped a horse for jihad" means: I gave it as charity to some of the fighters. [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Avoid the seven destructive sins." They said: "O Messenger of Allah, what are they?" He said: "Associating others with Allah, sorcery, killing a soul which Allah has forbidden except by right, consuming Riba, consuming the property of an orphan, turning back on the day of battle, and slandering chaste believing women who are unaware." (Agreed upon. "Al-Mawbiqat" means destructive.) [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, cursed the devourer of usury and the one who gives it." (Narrated by Muslim). Al-Tirmidhi and others added: "and its two witnesses, and its scribe." [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) say: "Allah the Almighty said: I am the most in need of partners, so whoever does an action in which he associates others with Me, I will abandon him and his association." (Narrated by Muslim). [Translated by Gemini 2.5 Flash]

And from him, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "The first of the people to be judged on the Day of Resurrection will be a man who was martyred. He will be brought, and his blessings will be shown to him, and he will recognize them. It will be said to him: 'What did you do with them?' He will say: 'I fought for you until I was martyred.' It will be said: 'You have lied. Rather, you fought so that it would be said that you are brave. And that has been said.' Then he will be ordered, and he will be dragged on his face until he is thrown into the Fire. And a man who learned knowledge and taught it, and recited the Quran. He will be brought, and his blessings will be shown to him, and he will recognize them. It will be said to him: 'What did you do with them?' He will say: 'I learned knowledge and taught it, and I recited the Quran for you.' It will be said: 'You have lied. Rather, you learned so that it would be said that you are a scholar. And you recited the Quran so that it would be said that you are a reciter. And that has been said.' Then he will be ordered, and he will be dragged on his face until he is thrown into the Fire. And a man whom Allah made wealthy and gave him all sorts of wealth. He will be brought, and his blessings will be shown to him, and he will recognize them. It will be said to him: 'What did you do with them?' He will say: 'I did not leave any way that you love to spend in, except that I spent in it for you.' It will be said: 'You have lied. Rather, you did it so that it would be said that you are generous. And that has been said.' Then he will be ordered, and he will be dragged on his face, and then thrown into the Fire."
